content.content:
1â†’# Big Meanie Project Conventions
     2â†’
     3â†’## Philosophy
     4â†’
     5â†’Big Meanie follows a radical simplicity approach: **break fast, fix immediately**. We prioritize clean breaks over compatibility layers because hidden issues compound exponentially. A breaking change that forces immediate fixes is better than subtle bugs that surface months later in production.
     6â†’
     7â†’## Table of Contents
     8â†’1. [Core Philosophy](#core-philosophy)
     9â†’2. [Naming Conventions](#naming-conventions)
    10â†’3. [No Backwards Compatibility](#no-backwards-compatibility)
    11â†’4. [Project Structure](#project-structure)
    12â†’5. [File Management](#file-management)
    13â†’6. [Code Organization](#code-organization)
    14â†’7. [Testing Standards](#testing-standards)
    15â†’8. [Documentation Rules](#documentation-rules)
    16â†’
    17â†’## Core Philosophy
    18â†’
    19â†’### The Big Meanie Way
    20â†’
    21â†’```go
    22â†’// We value:
    23â†’// 1. Clarity over cleverness
    24â†’// 2. Breaking changes over hidden complexity
    25â†’// 3. Direct solutions over abstractions
    26â†’// 4. Fast failures over graceful degradation
    27â†’// 5. Today's correctness over tomorrow's flexibility
    28â†’```
    29â†’
    30â†’### Design Principles
    31â†’
    32â†’```go
    33â†’// BAD: Maintaining compatibility
    34â†’type OrderService interface {
    35â†’    PlaceOrder(order Order) error
    36â†’    PlaceOrderV2(order OrderV2) error  // NEVER DO THIS
    37â†’}
    38â†’
    39â†’// GOOD: Clean break
    40â†’type OrderService interface {
    41â†’    PlaceOrder(order Order) error  // Just change it
    42â†’}
    43â†’
    44â†’// BAD: Migration code
    45â†’func MigrateData() {
    46â†’    if isOldFormat() {
    47â†’        convertToNew()  // NEVER DO THIS
    48â†’    }
    49â†’}
    50â†’
    51â†’// GOOD: Direct cutover
    52â†’func LoadData() {
    53â†’    // Assume new format only
    54â†’    // Old format fails fast
    55â†’}
    56â†’```
    57â†’
    58â†’## Naming Conventions
    59â†’
    60â†’### Concise Names
    61â†’
    62â†’Big Meanie uses ultra-concise naming. We prefer short, clear names over verbose descriptions.
    63â†’
    64â†’```go
    65â†’// BAD: Verbose naming
    66â†’type SupportResistanceCalculator struct {
    67â†’    maximumLookbackPeriod int
    68â†’    minimumVolumeThreshold decimal.Decimal
    69â†’}
    70â†’
    71â†’func CalculateSupportAndResistanceLevels() {}
    72â†’func GetMovingAverageConvergenceDivergence() {}
    73â†’
    74â†’// GOOD: Concise
    75â†’type SRCalculator struct {  // Support/Resistance
    76â†’    maxLookback int
    77â†’    minVol decimal.Decimal
    78â†’}
    79â†’
    80â†’func CalcSR() {}
    81â†’func MACD() {}
    82â†’```
    83â†’
    84â†’### Standard Abbreviations
    85â†’
    86â†’```go
    87â†’// Common trading abbreviations
    88â†’SR   // Support/Resistance
    89â†’MA   // Moving Average
    90â†’EMA  // Exponential Moving Average
    91â†’RSI  // Relative Strength Index
    92â†’MACD // Moving Average Convergence Divergence
    93â†’BB   // Bollinger Bands
    94â†’ATR  // Average True Range
    95â†’OBV  // On-Balance Volume
    96â†’MFI  // Money Flow Index
    97â†’
    98â†’// System abbreviations
    99â†’cfg  // config
   100â†’ctx  // context
   101â†’conn // connection
   102â†’db   // database
   103â†’err  // error
   104â†’msg  // message
   105â†’req  // request
   106â†’res  // response/result
   107â†’tx   // transaction
   108â†’
   109â†’// Trading specific
   110â†’qty  // quantity
   111â†’vol  // volume
   112â†’pos  // position
   113â†’pnl  // profit and loss
   114â†’nav  // net asset value
   115â†’liq  // liquidation/liquidity
   116â†’```
   117â†’
   118â†’### Method Names
   119â†’
   120â†’```go
   121â†’// Prefer short verbs
   122â†’Calc()  not  Calculate()
   123â†’Exec()  not  Execute()
   124â†’Init()  not  Initialize()
   125â†’Proc()  not  Process()
   126â†’Gen()   not  Generate()
   127â†’
   128â†’// Getters don't use Get
   129â†’Price()     not  GetPrice()
   130â†’Quantity()  not  GetQuantity()
   131â†’
   132â†’// Setters use Set
   133â†’SetPrice()
   134â†’SetQuantity()
   135â†’
   136â†’// Boolean methods
   137â†’IsValid()   not  CheckIfValid()
   138â†’HasData()   not  CheckHasData()
   139â†’CanTrade()  not  CheckCanTrade()
   140â†’```
   141â†’
   142â†’## No Backwards Compatibility
   143â†’
   144â†’### Breaking Changes Are Good
   145â†’
   146â†’```go
   147â†’// BAD: Versioned APIs
   148â†’func (api *API) RegisterHandlers() {
   149â†’    api.HandleFunc("/v1/orders", ordersV1Handler)
   150â†’    api.HandleFunc("/v2/orders", ordersV2Handler)  // NEVER
   151â†’}
   152â†’
   153â†’// GOOD: One version only
   154â†’func (api *API) RegisterHandlers() {
   155â†’    api.HandleFunc("/orders", ordersHandler)  // Break it, fix it
   156â†’}
   157â†’
   158â†’// BAD: Compatibility fields
   159â†’type Order struct {
   160â†’    ID       string
   161â†’    Price    decimal.Decimal
   162â†’
   163â†’    // Deprecated: Use Price instead
   164â†’    PriceStr string  // NEVER KEEP THIS
   165â†’}
   166â†’
   167â†’// GOOD: Clean structure
   168â†’type Order struct {
   169â†’    ID    string
   170â†’    Price decimal.Decimal  // Changed? Fix all usages
   171â†’}
   172â†’```
   173â†’
   174â†’### Migration Anti-Patterns to Avoid
   175â†’
   176â†’```go
   177â†’// NEVER: Gradual migration
   178â†’func LoadConfig() Config {
   179â†’    if FileExists("config.yaml") {
   180â†’        return LoadYAML()
   181â†’    }
   182â†’    // Fallback to old format
   183â†’    return LoadJSON()  // NEVER DO THIS
   184â†’}
   185â†’
   186â†’// ALWAYS: Direct cutover
   187â†’func LoadConfig() Config {
   188â†’    return LoadYAML()  // Old format fails immediately
   189â†’}
   190â†’
   191â†’// NEVER: Adapter patterns
   192â†’type LegacyAdapter struct {
   193â†’    newService *Service
   194â†’}
   195â†’
   196â†’func (a *LegacyAdapter) OldMethod() {
   197â†’    a.newService.NewMethod()  // NEVER BUILD ADAPTERS
   198â†’}
   199â†’
   200â†’// ALWAYS: Direct replacement
   201â†’// Just change OldMethod to NewMethod everywhere
   202â†’```
   203â†’
   204â†’### Database Migration Rules
   205â†’
   206â†’```sql
   207â†’-- BAD: Maintaining old columns
   208â†’ALTER TABLE orders ADD COLUMN price_decimal DECIMAL(20,8);
   209â†’UPDATE orders SET price_decimal = CAST(price_string AS DECIMAL);
   210â†’-- Keep both columns during "transition" - NEVER
   211â†’
   212â†’-- GOOD: Direct replacement
   213â†’ALTER TABLE orders DROP COLUMN price_string;
   214â†’ALTER TABLE orders ADD COLUMN price DECIMAL(20,8) NOT NULL;
   215â†’-- Breaks immediately, forces data migration
   216â†’```
   217â†’
   218â†’## Project Structure
   219â†’
   220â†’### Directory Layout
   221â†’
   222â†’```
   223â†’bigmeanie/
   224â†’â”œâ”€â”€ back/                 # Backend code
   225â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ .docs/           # Documentation (hidden)
   226â†’â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ archive/     # Historical docs (DO NOT REFERENCE)
   227â†’â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ code/        # Developer guidelines
   228â†’â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ pinescripts/ # TradingView source scripts
   229â†’â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ plan.md      # Current planning
   230â†’â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ todo.md      # Task tracking
   231â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ .snippets/       # Code patterns and examples (hidden)
   232â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ internal/        # Private packages (future)
   233â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ pkg/             # Public packages
   234â†’â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ clock/       # Time abstraction for testing
   235â†’â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ decimal_math/# High-precision math utilities
   236â†’â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ errors/      # Structured error handling framework
   237â†’â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ safego/      # Safe goroutine management for 24/7 operations
   238â†’â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ indicators/  # Technical analysis indicators
   239â†’â”‚   â”‚       â”œâ”€â”€ common/  # Standard indicators (RSI, ATR, VWAP)
   240â†’â”‚   â”‚       â”œâ”€â”€ pinescript/# Advanced indicators (ZLTS, MTO, AVOP)
   241â†’â”‚   â”‚       â””â”€â”€ vol_delta/# Volume delta calculations
   242â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ go.mod
   243â†’â”‚   â””â”€â”€ README.md
   244â†’â””â”€â”€ front/               # Frontend code
   245â†’    â””â”€â”€ README.md        # Currently empty - backend focus
   246â†’```
   247â†’
   248â†’### Package Organization
   249â†’
   250â†’```go
   251â†’// Each package has single responsibility
   252â†’// internal/engine/engine.go
   253â†’package engine
   254â†’
   255â†’type Engine struct {
   256â†’    // Only engine-related fields
   257â†’}
   258â†’
   259â†’// internal/strategy/strategy.go
   260â†’package strategy
   261â†’
   262â†’type Strategy interface {
   263â†’    // Only strategy methods
   264â†’}
   265â†’
   266â†’// Never mix concerns in one package
   267â†’// BAD: internal/trading/everything.go
   268â†’// GOOD: Separate packages for separate concerns
   269â†’```
   270â†’
   271â†’## File Management
   272â†’
   273â†’### No Variant Files
   274â†’
   275â†’```go
   276â†’// NEVER create these files:
   277â†’order.go
   278â†’order_v2.go      // NEVER
   279â†’order_new.go     // NEVER
   280â†’order_enhanced.go // NEVER
   281â†’order_refactored.go // NEVER
   282â†’
   283â†’// ALWAYS update the original:
   284â†’order.go  // Just change this file
   285â†’```
   286â†’
   287â†’### File Naming
   288â†’
   289â†’```go
   290â†’// Standard Go conventions
   291â†’order.go        // Types and methods
   292â†’order_test.go   // Tests
   293â†’doc.go         // Package documentation
   294â†’
   295â†’// Group by feature, not by type
   296â†’// BAD structure:
   297â†’types.go       // All types
   298â†’methods.go     // All methods
   299â†’interfaces.go  // All interfaces
   300â†’
   301â†’// GOOD structure:
   302â†’order.go       // Order type and methods
   303â†’trade.go       // Trade type and methods
   304â†’portfolio.go   // Portfolio type and methods
   305â†’```
   306â†’
   307â†’### Import Organization
   308â†’
   309â†’```go
   310â†’import (
   311â†’    // Standard library
   312â†’    "context"
   313â†’    "fmt"
   314â†’
   315â†’    // External dependencies
   316â†’    "github.com/shopspring/decimal"
   317â†’
   318â†’    // Internal packages
   319â†’    "bigmeanie/internal/engine"
   320â†’    "bigmeanie/pkg/indicators"
   321â†’)
   322â†’
   323â†’// Never use relative imports
   324â†’// BAD:  import "../engine"
   325â†’// GOOD: import "bigmeanie/internal/engine"
   326â†’```
   327â†’
   328â†’## Code Organization
   329â†’
   330â†’### Interface Design
   331â†’
   332â†’```go
   333â†’// Small, focused interfaces
   334â†’type Trader interface {
   335â†’    Trade(ctx context.Context, signal Signal) error
   336â†’}
   337â†’
   338â†’// Not large, kitchen-sink interfaces
   339â†’type BadTrader interface {
   340â†’    Trade() error
   341â†’    GetBalance() decimal.Decimal
   342â†’    GetHistory() []Trade
   343â†’    Configure(Config) error
   344â†’    // ... 20 more methods - NO!
   345â†’}
   346â†’
   347â†’// Compose interfaces when needed
   348â†’type FullTrader interface {
   349â†’    Trader
   350â†’    Backtester
   351â†’    Reporter
   352â†’}
   353â†’```
   354â†’
   355â†’### Error Handling
   356â†’
   357â†’```go
   358â†’// Always wrap errors with context
   359â†’if err != nil {
   360â†’    return fmt.Errorf("engine.Start: %w", err)
   361â†’}
   362â†’
   363â†’// Define sentinel errors
   364â†’var (
   365â†’    ErrInsufficientFunds = errors.New("insufficient funds")
   366â†’    ErrOrderTooSmall     = errors.New("order below minimum")
   367â†’    ErrExchangeDown      = errors.New("exchange unavailable")
   368â†’)
   369â†’
   370â†’// Use errors.Is for checking
   371â†’if errors.Is(err, ErrInsufficientFunds) {
   372â†’    // Handle specific error
   373â†’}
   374â†’```
   375â†’
   376â†’### Concurrency Patterns
   377â†’
   378â†’```go
   379â†’// Always use context for cancellation
   380â†’func (e *Engine) Run(ctx context.Context) error {
   381â†’    for {
   382â†’        select {
   383â†’        case <-ctx.Done():
   384â†’            return ctx.Err()
   385â†’        case signal := <-e.signals:
   386â†’            e.process(signal)
   387â†’        }
   388â†’    }
   389â†’}
   390â†’
   391â†’// Protect shared state
   392â†’type Portfolio struct {
   393â†’    mu       sync.RWMutex
   394â†’    balances map[string]decimal.Decimal
   395â†’}
   396â†’
   397â†’func (p *Portfolio) Balance(asset string) decimal.Decimal {
   398â†’    p.mu.RLock()
   399â†’    defer p.mu.RUnlock()
   400â†’    return p.balances[asset]
   401â†’}
   402â†’```
   403â†’
   404â†’## Testing Standards
   405â†’
   406â†’### Test Organization
   407â†’
   408â†’```go
   409â†’// Table-driven tests always
   410â†’func TestCalcSR(t *testing.T) {
   411â†’    tests := []struct {
   412â†’        name string
   413â†’        data []decimal.Decimal
   414â†’        want []Level
   415â†’    }{
   416â†’        {
   417â†’            name: "basic support",
   418â†’            data: []decimal.Decimal{...},
   419â†’            want: []Level{...},
   420â†’        },
   421â†’    }
   422â†’
   423â†’    for _, tt := range tests {
   424â†’        t.Run(tt.name, func(t *testing.T) {
   425â†’            got := CalcSR(tt.data)
   426â†’            require.Equal(t, tt.want, got)
   427â†’        })
   428â†’    }
   429â†’}
   430â†’
   431â†’// NEVER use t.Skip()
   432â†’// BAD:
   433â†’func TestBrokenFeature(t *testing.T) {
   434â†’    t.Skip("Fix later")  // NEVER
   435â†’}
   436â†’
   437â†’// GOOD: Fix it or delete it
   438â†’```
   439â†’
   440â†’### Test Coverage
   441â†’
   442â†’```go
   443â†’// Test edge cases
   444â†’func TestDivision(t *testing.T) {
   445â†’    // Test zero division
   446â†’    _, err := Divide(decimal.NewFromInt(1), decimal.Zero)
   447â†’    require.Error(t, err)
   448â†’
   449â†’    // Test negative values
   450â†’    result := Divide(decimal.NewFromInt(-10), decimal.NewFromInt(2))
   451â†’    require.Equal(t, decimal.NewFromInt(-5), result)
   452â†’}
   453â†’
   454â†’// Benchmark hot paths
   455â†’func BenchmarkCalcSR(b *testing.B) {
   456â†’    data := generatePriceData(1000)
   457â†’    b.ResetTimer()
   458â†’
   459â†’    for i := 0; i < b.N; i++ {
   460â†’        CalcSR(data)
   461â†’    }
   462â†’}
   463â†’```
   464â†’
   465â†’## Documentation Rules
   466â†’
   467â†’### Code Comments
   468â†’
   469â†’```go
   470â†’// Document WHY, not WHAT
   471â†’// BAD:
   472â†’// Increment counter by 1
   473â†’counter++
   474â†’
   475â†’// GOOD:
   476â†’// Retry count for exchange rate limiting
   477â†’counter++
   478â†’
   479â†’// Document edge cases
   480â†’// Returns -1 if no valid price found
   481â†’func FindPrice(prices []decimal.Decimal) decimal.Decimal {
   482â†’    // ...
   483â†’}
   484â†’
   485â†’// Document assumptions
   486â†’// Assumes prices are sorted in ascending order
   487â†’func BinarySearch(prices []decimal.Decimal, target decimal.Decimal) int {
   488â†’    // ...
   489â†’}
   490â†’```
   491â†’
   492â†’### Package Documentation
   493â†’
   494â†’```go
   495â†’// Package engine implements the core trading engine for Big Meanie.
   496â†’//
   497â†’// The engine coordinates between strategy signals, risk management,
   498â†’// and exchange execution. It runs continuously, processing signals
   499â†’// and managing positions according to configured strategies.
   500â†’//
   501â†’// Basic usage:
   502â†’//
   503â†’//	cfg := engine.DefaultConfig()
   504â†’//	eng := engine.New(cfg)
   505â†’//	err := eng.Run(ctx)
   506â†’//
   507â†’package engine
   508â†’```
   509â†’
   510â†’### README Files
   511â†’
   512â†’```markdown
   513â†’# Component Name
   514â†’
   515â†’## Purpose
   516â†’One paragraph explaining what this does and why it exists.
   517â†’
   518â†’## Usage
   519â†’Code examples showing common usage patterns.
   520â†’
   521â†’## Configuration
   522â†’Environment variables or config files needed.
   523â†’
   524â†’## Testing
   525â†’How to run tests for this component.
   526â†’
   527â†’Never create documentation unless explicitly requested.
   528â†’Document in code, not in separate files.
   529â†’```
   530â†’
   531â†’## Anti-Patterns to Avoid
   532â†’
   533â†’### Never Do These
   534â†’
   535â†’```go
   536â†’// 1. Backwards compatibility layers
   537â†’type Service struct {
   538â†’    v1Client *ClientV1
   539â†’    v2Client *ClientV2  // NEVER
   540â†’}
   541â†’
   542â†’// 2. Gradual migrations
   543â†’if useNewSystem {
   544â†’    processNew()
   545â†’} else {
   546â†’    processOld()  // NEVER
   547â†’}
   548â†’
   549â†’// 3. Deprecation warnings
   550â†’// Deprecated: Use NewMethod instead
   551â†’func OldMethod() {  // Just delete it
   552â†’}
   553â†’
   554â†’// 4. Feature flags for old behavior
   555â†’if featureFlag("use-old-algorithm") {  // NEVER
   556â†’    oldAlgorithm()
   557â†’}
   558â†’
   559â†’// 5. Compatibility shims
   560â†’func shimOldToNew(old Old) New {  // NEVER
   561â†’    // Convert old format to new
   562â†’}
   563â†’
   564â†’// 6. Variant files
   565â†’order_v2.go      // NEVER
   566â†’order_new.go     // NEVER
   567â†’order_temp.go    // NEVER
   568â†’
   569â†’// 7. TODO comments for compatibility
   570â†’// TODO: Remove after all clients updated  // NEVER
   571â†’```
   572â†’
   573â†’## Summary of Conventions
   574â†’
   575â†’1. **Ultra-concise naming** - SR not SupportResistance
   576â†’2. **No backwards compatibility** - Break it cleanly
   577â†’3. **No migration code** - Direct cutover only
   578â†’4. **No variant files** - Update the original
   579â†’5. **Fast failures** - Errors surface immediately
   580â†’6. **Single version** - No v1, v2 APIs
   581â†’7. **Clean breaks** - Force immediate fixes
   582â†’8. **Direct solutions** - No adapter patterns
   583â†’9. **Test everything** - Never skip tests
   584â†’10. **Document WHY** - Code explains what, comments explain why
   585â†’
   586â†’Remember: **Every line of compatibility code is technical debt.** Break fast, fix immediately, move forward.
   587â†’

Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it looks malicious. If it does, you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer high-level questions about the code behavior.

content.content:
1â†’# Big Meanie Architecture & Implementation Plan
     2â†’
     3â†’## Executive Summary
     4â†’
     5â†’This document consolidates the architectural and implementation plans for the Big Meanie trading system. It covers critical infrastructure components including the TimeSeries data management solution and the custom test package to replace testify. Both designs follow the project's core principles of minimal dependencies, no backwards compatibility, and clean Go idiomatic code.
     6â†’
     7â†’## 1. Core Infrastructure Components
     8â†’
     9â†’### 1.1 TimeSeries Architecture
    10â†’
    11â†’The indicators package requires a TimeSeries solution to manage OHLCV data for technical analysis. After analyzing requirements and existing code patterns, the recommendation is to build a **custom minimal TimeSeries package** that aligns with Go idioms and project principles.
    12â†’
    13â†’#### 1.1.a Requirements Analysis
    14â†’
    15â†’**Data Management Requirements:**
    16â†’- Store OHLCV candles (Open, High, Low, Close, Volume) with timestamps
    17â†’- Support both fixed-size windows (for live trading) and growing datasets (for backtesting)
    18â†’- Efficient access by index for indicator calculations
    19â†’- Thread-safe for concurrent indicator calculations
    20â†’
    21â†’**Interface Requirements (from indicators/interfaces.go):**
    22â†’```go
    23â†’type TimeSeries interface {
    24â†’    Symbol() string
    25â†’    Len() int
    26â†’    GetCandle(index int) *types.Candle
    27â†’    LastCandle() *types.Candle
    28â†’    LastIndex() int
    29â†’}
    30â†’```
    31â†’
    32â†’**Performance Requirements:**
    33â†’- Fast random access for indicator calculations
    34â†’- Minimal memory allocations during updates
    35â†’- Support datasets of 100K+ candles for backtesting
    36â†’- Sub-millisecond updates for live trading
    37â†’
    38â†’**Usage Patterns Observed:**
    39â†’- Sequential access patterns during precalculation
    40â†’- Random access for lookback periods
    41â†’- Cache-friendly iteration over ranges
    42â†’- Read-heavy workload (write once, read many)
    43â†’
    44â†’#### 1.1.b Design Decisions
    45â†’
    46â†’**Build vs Buy Analysis:**
    47â†’
    48â†’Existing Go TimeSeries libraries were evaluated:
    49â†’1. **github.com/influxdata/influxdb/pkg/tsdb** - Heavy dependency, overkill
    50â†’2. **github.com/VividCortex/gohistogram** - Histogram-focused, not OHLCV
    51â†’3. **github.com/go-kit/kit/metrics** - Metrics-focused, wrong abstraction
    52â†’
    53â†’**Decision: Build Custom Solution**
    54â†’- âœ… Zero external dependencies
    55â†’- âœ… Tailored to exact needs
    56â†’- âœ… Follows project principles
    57â†’- âœ… Simple, maintainable code (~300 LOC)
    58â†’
    59â†’**Architecture Decisions:**
    60â†’
    61â†’1. **Two Implementation Strategy:**
    62â†’   - `FixedWindow`: For live trading (sliding window, bounded memory)
    63â†’   - `Growing`: For backtesting (append-only, unbounded)
    64â†’   - Common interface allows indicators to work with both
    65â†’
    66â†’2. **Value Semantics for Candles:**
    67â†’   - Store by value in slices for cache locality
    68â†’   - Return pointers to avoid copying large structs
    69â†’
    70â†’3. **Sync.RWMutex for Thread Safety:**
    71â†’   - Read-heavy workload benefits from RWMutex
    72â†’   - Allows multiple concurrent indicator calculations
    73â†’
    74â†’4. **Pre-allocation Strategy:**
    75â†’   - Growing: Start with capacity hint
    76â†’   - FixedWindow: Allocate full size upfront
    77â†’
    78â†’#### 1.1.c Package Design
    79â†’
    80â†’**Package Structure:**
    81â†’```
    82â†’pkg/ts/
    83â†’â”œâ”€â”€ ts.go           # Interfaces and types
    84â†’â”œâ”€â”€ fixed.go        # Fixed-size window implementation
    85â†’â”œâ”€â”€ growing.go      # Growing series implementation
    86â†’â”œâ”€â”€ candle.go       # Candle type and methods
    87â†’â””â”€â”€ ts_test.go      # Comprehensive tests
    88â†’```
    89â†’
    90â†’**Core Types:**
    91â†’```go
    92â†’// Candle represents OHLCV data point
    93â†’type Candle struct {
    94â†’    Symbol    string
    95â†’    Timestamp time.Time
    96â†’    Open      decimal.Decimal
    97â†’    High      decimal.Decimal
    98â†’    Low       decimal.Decimal
    99â†’    Close     decimal.Decimal
   100â†’    Volume    decimal.Decimal
   101â†’}
   102â†’
   103â†’// Series interface for all TimeSeries implementations
   104â†’type Series interface {
   105â†’    Symbol() string
   106â†’    Len() int
   107â†’    GetCandle(index int) *Candle
   108â†’    LastCandle() *Candle
   109â†’    LastIndex() int
   110â†’    Add(candle Candle)
   111â†’    Clear()
   112â†’}
   113â†’```
   114â†’
   115â†’#### 1.1.d Implementation Details
   116â†’
   117â†’**Fixed Window Implementation:**
   118â†’- Circular buffer for memory efficiency
   119â†’- Logical to physical index mapping
   120â†’- Thread-safe with RWMutex
   121â†’- Pre-allocated array of fixed size
   122â†’
   123â†’**Growing Implementation:**
   124â†’- Append-only slice with capacity hints
   125â†’- Direct index access
   126â†’- Thread-safe with RWMutex
   127â†’- Dynamic growth as needed
   128â†’
   129â†’#### 1.1.e Integration Strategy
   130â†’
   131â†’1. **Create types package first** with Candle type alias
   132â†’2. **Update indicator interfaces** to use new types
   133â†’3. **Both ts.Fixed and ts.Growing** satisfy the interface
   134â†’
   135â†’**Usage Examples:**
   136â†’
   137â†’Backtesting:
   138â†’```go
   139â†’series := ts.NewGrowing("BTC/USD", 10000)
   140â†’for _, candle := range historicalData {
   141â†’    series.Add(candle)
   142â†’}
   143â†’rsi := indicators.NewRSI(series, 14)
   144â†’```
   145â†’
   146â†’Live Trading:
   147â†’```go
   148â†’series := ts.NewFixed("BTC/USD", 500)
   149â†’for candle := range candleStream {
   150â†’    series.Add(candle)
   151â†’}
   152â†’```
   153â†’
   154â†’#### 1.1.f Performance Optimizations
   155â†’
   156â†’**Memory Layout:**
   157â†’- Store Candles by value for cache locality
   158â†’- Align struct fields for optimal padding
   159â†’- Pre-allocate slices to avoid growths
   160â†’
   161â†’**Concurrency:**
   162â†’- RWMutex allows multiple readers
   163â†’- Lock-free reads where possible
   164â†’- Consider atomic operations for metadata
   165â†’
   166â†’**Future Optimizations:**
   167â†’- Memory pool for Candle allocations
   168â†’- SIMD operations for bulk calculations
   169â†’- Custom iterator for cache-friendly traversal
   170â†’
   171â†’### 1.2 Test Package Design
   172â†’

# Big Meanie Architecture & Implementation Plan

## Executive Summary

This document consolidates the architectural and implementation plans for the Big Meanie trading system. It covers critical infrastructure components including the TimeSeries data management solution and the custom test package to replace testify. Both designs follow the project's core principles of minimal dependencies, no backwards compatibility, and clean Go idiomatic code.

## 1. Core Infrastructure Components

### 1.1 TimeSeries Architecture

The indicators package requires a TimeSeries solution to manage OHLCV data for technical analysis. After analyzing requirements and existing code patterns, the recommendation is to build a **custom minimal TimeSeries package** that aligns with Go idioms and project principles.

#### 1.1.a Requirements Analysis

**Data Management Requirements:**
- Store OHLCV candles (Open, High, Low, Close, Volume) with timestamps
- Support both fixed-size windows (for live trading) and growing datasets (for backtesting)
- Efficient access by index for indicator calculations
- Thread-safe for concurrent indicator calculations

**Interface Requirements (from indicators/interfaces.go):**
```go
type TimeSeries interface {
    Symbol() string
    Len() int
    GetCandle(index int) *types.Candle
    LastCandle() *types.Candle
    LastIndex() int
}
```

**Performance Requirements:**
- Fast random access for indicator calculations
- Minimal memory allocations during updates
- Support datasets of 100K+ candles for backtesting
- Sub-millisecond updates for live trading

**Usage Patterns Observed:**
- Sequential access patterns during precalculation
- Random access for lookback periods
- Cache-friendly iteration over ranges
- Read-heavy workload (write once, read many)

#### 1.1.b Design Decisions

**Build vs Buy Analysis:**

Existing Go TimeSeries libraries were evaluated:
1. **github.com/influxdata/influxdb/pkg/tsdb** - Heavy dependency, overkill
2. **github.com/VividCortex/gohistogram** - Histogram-focused, not OHLCV
3. **github.com/go-kit/kit/metrics** - Metrics-focused, wrong abstraction

**Decision: Build Custom Solution**
- âœ… Zero external dependencies
- âœ… Tailored to exact needs
- âœ… Follows project principles
- âœ… Simple, maintainable code (~300 LOC)

**Architecture Decisions:**

1. **Two Implementation Strategy:**
   - `FixedWindow`: For live trading (sliding window, bounded memory)
   - `Growing`: For backtesting (append-only, unbounded)
   - Common interface allows indicators to work with both

2. **Value Semantics for Candles:**
   - Store by value in slices for cache locality
   - Return pointers to avoid copying large structs

3. **Sync.RWMutex for Thread Safety:**
   - Read-heavy workload benefits from RWMutex
   - Allows multiple concurrent indicator calculations

4. **Pre-allocation Strategy:**
   - Growing: Start with capacity hint
   - FixedWindow: Allocate full size upfront

#### 1.1.c Package Design

**Package Structure:**
```
pkg/ts/
â”œâ”€â”€ ts.go           # Interfaces and types
â”œâ”€â”€ fixed.go        # Fixed-size window implementation
â”œâ”€â”€ growing.go      # Growing series implementation
â”œâ”€â”€ candle.go       # Candle type and methods
â””â”€â”€ ts_test.go      # Comprehensive tests
```

**Core Types:**
```go
// Candle represents OHLCV data point
type Candle struct {
    Symbol    string
    Timestamp time.Time
    Open      decimal.Decimal
    High      decimal.Decimal
    Low       decimal.Decimal
    Close     decimal.Decimal
    Volume    decimal.Decimal
}

// Series interface for all TimeSeries implementations
type Series interface {
    Symbol() string
    Len() int
    GetCandle(index int) *Candle
    LastCandle() *Candle
    LastIndex() int
    Add(candle Candle)
    Clear()
}
```

#### 1.1.d Implementation Details

**Fixed Window Implementation:**
- Circular buffer for memory efficiency
- Logical to physical index mapping
- Thread-safe with RWMutex
- Pre-allocated array of fixed size

**Growing Implementation:**
- Append-only slice with capacity hints
- Direct index access
- Thread-safe with RWMutex
- Dynamic growth as needed

#### 1.1.e Integration Strategy

1. **Create types package first** with Candle type alias
2. **Update indicator interfaces** to use new types
3. **Both ts.Fixed and ts.Growing** satisfy the interface

**Usage Examples:**

Backtesting:
```go
series := ts.NewGrowing("BTC/USD", 10000)
for _, candle := range historicalData {
    series.Add(candle)
}
rsi := indicators.NewRSI(series, 14)
```

Live Trading:
```go
series := ts.NewFixed("BTC/USD", 500)
for candle := range candleStream {
    series.Add(candle)
}
```

#### 1.1.f Performance Optimizations

**Memory Layout:**
- Store Candles by value for cache locality
- Align struct fields for optimal padding
- Pre-allocate slices to avoid growths

**Concurrency:**
- RWMutex allows multiple readers
- Lock-free reads where possible
- Consider atomic operations for metadata

**Future Optimizations:**
- Memory pool for Candle allocations
- SIMD operations for bulk calculations
- Custom iterator for cache-friendly traversal

### 1.2 Test Package Design

Replace testify dependency which brings yaml.v3 as an indirect dependency, creating technical debt and potential security vulnerabilities.

#### 1.2.a Problem Analysis

**Current Issue:**
- testify v1.8.4 brings in `gopkg.in/yaml.v3` as indirect dependency
- yaml.v3 is outdated/deprecated (2 versions behind)
- Violates principle of minimal dependencies

**Usage Analysis:**
- 21 test files using testify
- Only using `assert` and `require` packages
- Most used: Equal (47), NoError (32), NotNil (18), Nil (12)

#### 1.2.b Solution Design

**Recommendation: Custom Test Package**

Create minimal `pkg/test/` package with zero external dependencies.

**Pros:**
- Zero external dependencies
- Concise naming aligned with project standards
- Tailored to actual usage
- Can add decimal-specific assertions later
- Full control over implementation

**Package Structure:**
```
pkg/test/
â”œâ”€â”€ assert.go      # Non-fatal assertions
â”œâ”€â”€ require.go     # Fatal assertions  
â”œâ”€â”€ test_test.go   # Tests for the test package
â””â”€â”€ README.md      # Documentation
```

#### 1.2.c API Design

**Core Assertions:**
```go
// Comparison
func Equal[T comparable](t *testing.T, expected, actual T, msgs ...string)
func NotEqual[T comparable](t *testing.T, expected, actual T, msgs ...string)

// Nil checks
func Nil(t *testing.T, v any, msgs ...string)
func NotNil(t *testing.T, v any, msgs ...string)

// Boolean
func True(t *testing.T, v bool, msgs ...string)
func False(t *testing.T, v bool, msgs ...string)

// Collections
func Empty(t *testing.T, v any, msgs ...string)
func NotEmpty(t *testing.T, v any, msgs ...string)
func Contains(t *testing.T, container, item any, msgs ...string)
func Len(t *testing.T, v any, expected int, msgs ...string)

// Errors
func Error(t *testing.T, err error, msgs ...string)
func NoError(t *testing.T, err error, msgs ...string)

// Numeric
func Greater[T Ordered](t *testing.T, actual, expected T, msgs ...string)
func InDelta(t *testing.T, expected, actual, delta float64, msgs ...string)
```

**Fatal Assertions (require.go):**
```go
func RequireEqual[T comparable](t *testing.T, expected, actual T, msgs ...string)
func RequireNoError(t *testing.T, err error, msgs ...string)
func RequireNotNil(t *testing.T, v any, msgs ...string)
```

#### 1.2.d Migration Strategy

**Phase 1: Create Testing Package**
1. Create `pkg/test/` directory
2. Implement core assertion functions
3. Write comprehensive tests
4. Ensure 100% compatibility with existing patterns

**Phase 2: Automated Migration**
1. Replace imports via script
2. Replace function calls using sed/awk
3. Map all testify functions to new equivalents

**Phase 3: Verification**
1. Run all tests to ensure they pass
2. Remove testify from go.mod
3. Verify yaml.v3 is removed

## 2. Implementation Roadmap

### 2.1 TimeSeries Implementation

#### 2.1.a Phase 1: Core Implementation (2-3 hours)
- [ ] Create pkg/ts package structure
- [ ] Implement Candle type
- [ ] Implement Fixed window
- [ ] Implement Growing series
- [ ] Write comprehensive tests

#### 2.1.b Phase 2: Integration (1-2 hours)
- [ ] Create pkg/types with Candle alias
- [ ] Update indicator interfaces
- [ ] Test with existing indicators
- [ ] Fix any integration issues

#### 2.1.c Phase 3: Optimization (Optional)
- [ ] Profile with real data
- [ ] Optimize hot paths
- [ ] Add specialized methods if needed

### 2.2 Test Package Implementation

#### 2.2.a Implementation Checklist
- [ ] Create pkg/test directory structure
- [ ] Implement Equal, NotEqual, Nil, NotNil functions
- [ ] Implement True, False boolean functions
- [ ] Implement Error, NoError error functions
- [ ] Implement Empty, NotEmpty, Len collection functions
- [ ] Implement Contains, NotContains functions
- [ ] Implement Greater, GreaterEqual, Less, LessEqual comparison functions
- [ ] Implement InDelta for float comparisons
- [ ] Implement Zero function
- [ ] Implement Require versions (RequireNoError, RequireNotNil, RequireEqual)
- [ ] Write comprehensive tests for test package
- [ ] Create migration script
- [ ] Migrate existing test files
- [ ] Remove testify from go.mod
- [ ] Verify yaml.v3 is removed
- [ ] Update documentation

## 3. Testing Strategy

### 3.1 TimeSeries Testing

**Unit Tests:**
- Test both Fixed and Growing implementations
- Concurrent access tests
- Boundary conditions (empty, single, full)
- Circular buffer correctness for Fixed

**Benchmarks:**
```go
func BenchmarkFixedAdd(b *testing.B)
func BenchmarkFixedGet(b *testing.B)
func BenchmarkGrowingAdd(b *testing.B)
func BenchmarkGrowingGet(b *testing.B)
func BenchmarkConcurrentReads(b *testing.B)
```

**Integration Tests:**
- Test with actual indicators
- Verify thread safety with race detector
- Memory leak detection

### 3.2 Test Package Testing

- Comprehensive testing of the test package itself
- Edge cases in assertion logic
- Behavioral compatibility with testify
- Full test suite verification after migration

## 4. Risk Analysis

### 4.1 TimeSeries Risks

**Risks:**
- Initial bugs â†’ Mitigate with comprehensive testing
- Missing features â†’ Start minimal, extend as needed
- Performance issues â†’ Profile early, optimize based on data

**Benefits:**
- Zero dependencies â†’ No supply chain risks
- Perfect fit â†’ Exactly what indicators need
- Maintainable â†’ Simple, clear code
- Extensible â†’ Easy to add features

### 4.2 Test Package Risks

**Risks:**
- Initial implementation bugs in test package
- Missing edge cases in assertion logic
- Developer familiarity with new API

**Mitigation:**
- Comprehensive testing of test package itself
- Start with most common assertions first
- Keep API similar to testify for easy transition
- Document any behavioral differences clearly
- Run full test suite after each migration batch

## 5. Decision Matrices

### 5.1 TimeSeries Decision Matrix

| Criteria | Custom Package | External Library | Hybrid Approach |
|----------|---------------|------------------|-----------------|
| Dependencies | â­â­â­â­â­ (Zero) | â­â­ (Multiple) | â­â­â­ (Some) |
| Performance | â­â­â­â­â­ (Optimized) | â­â­â­ (Generic) | â­â­â­â­ (Good) |
| Maintainability | â­â­â­â­ (Simple) | â­â­ (External) | â­â­â­ (Complex) |
| Flexibility | â­â­â­â­â­ (Full control) | â­â­ (Limited) | â­â­â­â­ (Good) |
| Development Time | â­â­â­ (3-4 hours) | â­â­â­â­â­ (Immediate) | â­â­ (Days) |
| Go Idiomatic | â­â­â­â­â­ (Yes) | â­â­â­ (Varies) | â­â­â­â­ (Mostly) |

**Recommendation: Custom Package**

### 5.2 Test Package Decision Matrix

| Criteria | Custom Test Package | Keep Testify | Alternative Library |
|----------|-------------------|--------------|-------------------|
| Dependencies | â­â­â­â­â­ (Zero) | â­ (yaml.v3) | â­â­ (Various) |
| Migration Effort | â­â­â­ (Automated) | â­â­â­â­â­ (None) | â­â­ (Manual) |
| Maintainability | â­â­â­â­â­ (Full control) | â­â­ (External) | â­â­â­ (External) |
| API Familiarity | â­â­â­â­ (Similar) | â­â­â­â­â­ (Same) | â­â­ (Different) |
| Extensibility | â­â­â­â­â­ (Custom) | â­â­ (Limited) | â­â­â­ (Varies) |

**Recommendation: Custom Test Package**

## 6. Future Extensions

### 6.1 TimeSeries Extensions

Once the basic implementation is working:
- Memory pool for Candle allocations
- SIMD operations for bulk calculations
- Custom iterator for cache-friendly traversal
- Specialized aggregation methods
- Time-based queries and windowing

### 6.2 Test Package Extensions

Once the basic package is working:
- Decimal-specific assertions for shopspring/decimal
- Slice comparison helpers
- Map comparison helpers
- JSON comparison utilities
- Benchmark helpers
- Test fixture management
- Golden file testing utilities

## 7. Benefits Summary

### 7.1 Overall Project Benefits

**Immediate Benefits:**
- Removes all indirect test dependencies (yaml.v3)
- Reduces dependency tree complexity significantly
- Provides tailored TimeSeries solution for indicators
- Maintains zero external dependencies principle

**Long-term Benefits:**
- Full control over critical infrastructure
- No external breaking changes to worry about
- Can evolve with project needs
- Consistent with project principles
- Easier onboarding with clear, simple code

### 7.2 Technical Excellence

Both solutions demonstrate commitment to:
- **Minimal dependencies** - Zero external dependencies
- **No backwards compatibility** - Clean implementations
- **Go idiomatic code** - Following standard patterns
- **Performance focus** - Optimized for specific use cases
- **Maintainability** - Simple, clear, testable code

## 8. Conclusion

These infrastructure components form the foundation of the Big Meanie trading system. Both the TimeSeries package and custom test package:

1. **Align with project principles** - Minimal dependencies, no tech debt
2. **Provide simple implementations** - Combined ~500 lines of clear code
3. **Offer performance optimization** - Tailored for specific use cases
4. **Ensure future flexibility** - Full control over evolution
5. **Follow Go best practices** - Standard patterns and idioms

The implementations are straightforward, well-bounded, and directly address the needs of the project without introducing external dependencies or unnecessary complexity. This approach ensures the codebase remains lean, maintainable, and performant as it grows.

Perfect! Now I have a comprehensive understanding of the Big Meanie codebase. Let me provide a detailed summary of what I've learned:

## ðŸ“Š Big Meanie Trading System - Codebase Analysis Summary

### **System Overview**
Big Meanie is a 24/7 cryptocurrency trading bot built in Go, designed for high-performance automated trading with support for multiple exchanges, spot/futures/perpetual trading, and complete feature parity between backtesting and live trading environments.

### **Core Philosophy & Principles**

#### ðŸ”¥ **"Break Fast, Fix Immediately"**
- **NO backwards compatibility** - Breaking changes force immediate fixes
- **NO migration code** - Direct cutover only, no transition periods
- **NO compatibility layers** - Clean breaks prevent hidden technical debt
- **Fast Fail approach** - Errors surface immediately, not months later in production

#### ðŸ’Ž **Key Design Principles**
1. **Ultra-concise naming** - `SR` not `SupportResistance`, `Calc()` not `Calculate()`
2. **shopspring/decimal for ALL numeric operations** - No float64 for financial calculations
3. **Table-driven tests** - Always, with testify (soon custom test package)
4. **Never use `t.Skip()`** - Fix it or delete it
5. **Single version APIs** - No v1/v2 endpoints
6. **No variant files** - Never create `_v2`, `_new`, `_enhanced` files

### **Architecture & Structure**

#### ðŸ“ **Project Layout**
```
bigmeanie/
â”œâ”€â”€ back/                       # Backend (Go)
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ .docs/                 # Documentation
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ code/              # Developer guidelines
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ pinescripts/       # TradingView scripts
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ plan.md            # Current planning
â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ todo.md            # Task tracking
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ pkg/                   # Public packages
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ clock/             # Time abstraction for testing
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ decimal_math/      # High-precision math utilities
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ errors/            # Structured error handling
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ safego/            # Safe goroutine management
â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ indicators/        # Technical analysis
â”‚   â”‚       â”œâ”€â”€ common/        # Standard indicators (RSI, ATR, VWAP)
â”‚   â”‚       â”œâ”€â”€ pinescript/    # Advanced indicators
â”‚   â”‚       â””â”€â”€ vol_delta/     # Volume delta calculations
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ internal/              # Private packages (future)
â””â”€â”€ front/                     # Frontend (future)
```

### **Technical Patterns & Guidelines**

#### ðŸ”¢ **Decimal Operations (shopspring/decimal)**
- **ALWAYS use decimal** for money, prices, quantities, percentages
- **NEVER use float64** for financial calculations
- Parse from strings for precision: `decimal.RequireFromString("100.123")`
- Check for zero before division
- Round appropriately for display vs calculation

```go
// Example from documentation
price := decimal.RequireFromString("100.50")
quantity := decimal.RequireFromString("2.5")
total := price.Mul(quantity)  // 251.25
```

#### âš¡ **Concurrency Patterns**
- **Goroutine lifecycle management** - Always know how they'll stop
- **Context for cancellation** - Check `ctx.Done()` in loops
- **Channel ownership** - Creator closes, receiver checks
- **Worker pools** with bounded concurrency
- **sync.RWMutex** for read-heavy workloads
- **Graceful shutdown** with signal handling

```go
// Example pattern
func (e *Engine) Run(ctx context.Context) error {
    for {
        select {
        case <-ctx.Done():
            return ctx.Err()
        case signal := <-e.signals:
            e.process(signal)
        }
    }
}
```

#### ðŸ“¦ **Package Design**
- **Single responsibility** per package
- **Small, focused interfaces** - "Accept interfaces, return structs"
- **Internal packages** for non-public code
- **No circular dependencies** - Use interfaces to break cycles
- **Minimal public API** - Export only what's necessary

#### ðŸ§ª **Testing Standards**
- **Table-driven tests** always
- **>80% coverage** target
- **Benchmarks** for performance-critical code
- **Race detector** during development (`go test -race`)
- **Fast tests** - If >5 min, split them
- **Mock external APIs** - Don't let third-party services break tests

### **Current Implementation Status**

#### âœ… **Implemented Components**
1. **clock** - Time abstraction with mock support for deterministic testing
2. **decimal_math** - High-precision financial calculations utilities
3. **errors** - Structured error handling with context wrapping
4. **safego** - Safe goroutine management for 24/7 operations
5. **indicators/common** - Standard technical indicators:
   - RSI (Relative Strength Index)
   - ATR (Average True Range)
   - VWAP (Volume Weighted Average Price)
   - OBV (On-Balance Volume)
   - MFI (Money Flow Index)
   - CMF (Chaikin Money Flow)
   - VROC (Volume Rate of Change)
   - Support/Resistance levels

#### ðŸš§ **Planned Components** (from plan.md)
1. **TimeSeries Package** - Custom OHLCV data management
   - Fixed window for live trading
   - Growing series for backtesting
   - Thread-safe with RWMutex
   - Zero external dependencies

2. **Custom Test Package** - Replace testify to remove yaml.v3 dependency
   - Minimal assertion functions
   - Zero external dependencies
   - Compatible API for easy migration

### **Key Design Decisions**

#### ðŸŽ¯ **Build vs Buy Philosophy**
- **Build custom solutions** when external libraries bring unnecessary dependencies
- **Zero tolerance** for indirect dependencies (e.g., yaml.v3 via testify)
- **Tailored implementations** over generic libraries
- Example: Building custom TimeSeries instead of using heavy external libraries

#### ðŸ”„ **Data Flow Architecture**
1. **Exchange data** â†’ TimeSeries storage
2. **TimeSeries** â†’ Indicator calculations
3. **Indicators** â†’ Strategy signals
4. **Signals** â†’ Risk management
5. **Risk approval** â†’ Order execution
6. **Execution** â†’ Position tracking

### **Code Quality Standards**

#### âœ¨ **Clean Code Practices**
- **Document WHY, not WHAT** in comments
- **Error wrapping** with context: `fmt.Errorf("engine.Start: %w", err)`
- **Sentinel errors** for known conditions
- **Defer cleanup** immediately after resource acquisition
- **Early returns** to reduce nesting
- **Immutable configurations** - Copy-on-write patterns

#### ðŸš« **Anti-Patterns to Avoid**
- Backwards compatibility layers
- Gradual migrations
- Deprecation warnings (just delete it)
- Feature flags for old behavior
- Compatibility shims
- Variant files (_v2, _new, _temp)
- TODO comments for compatibility

### **Performance Considerations**

#### âš¡ **Optimization Strategies**
- **Pre-allocate slices** when size is known
- **sync.Pool** for frequently allocated objects
- **Pointer receivers** for large structs
- **Cache-friendly** data structures
- **Batch operations** for efficiency
- **Profile before optimizing** - Measure, don't guess

### **Development Workflow**

#### ðŸ”§ **Standard Practices**
- Small commits doing one thing
- Never break the build
- Clear commit messages
- Run tests before committing
- Format code with `go fmt`
- Use `go mod tidy` to clean dependencies

#### ðŸ“ **Documentation Requirements**
- Document all exported items with godoc
- Start comments with the name being declared
- Provide usage examples
- Never create documentation unless explicitly requested
- Keep documentation in code, not separate files

### **Security & Reliability**

#### ðŸ”’ **Security Practices**
- Environment variables for configuration
- Never commit secrets
- Input validation and sanitization
- Monthly security updates for dependencies
- Error tracking (Sentry or similar) for production

#### ðŸ›¡ï¸ **Reliability Features**
- Graceful shutdown handling
- Health checks and readiness probes
- Structured logging with context
- Metrics and observability hooks
- Idempotent operations
- Background job deduplication

### **Summary**

Big Meanie represents a clean, performance-focused approach to cryptocurrency trading systems. The codebase emphasizes:
- **Radical simplicity** through breaking changes over compatibility
- **Performance** through Go's concurrency and careful optimization
- **Reliability** through comprehensive testing and error handling
- **Maintainability** through clear structure and minimal dependencies

The system is designed to run 24/7 with high reliability, supporting multiple exchanges and trading strategies while maintaining clean, idiomatic Go code throughout.

```go
price := decimal.RequireFromString("100.50")
quantity := decimal.RequireFromString("2.5")
total := price.Mul(quantity)  // 251.25
```

#### âš¡ **Concurrency Patterns**
- **Goroutine lifecycle management** - Always know how they'll stop
- **Context for cancellation** - Check `ctx.Done()` in loops
- **Channel ownership** - Creator closes, receiver checks
- **Worker pools** with bounded concurrency
- **sync.RWMutex** for read-heavy workloads
- **Graceful shutdown** with signal handling

```go
// Example pattern
func (e *Engine) Run(ctx context.Context) error {
    for {
        select {
        case <-ctx.Done():
            return ctx.Err()
        case signal := <-e.signals:
            e.process(signal)
        }
    }
}
```

#### ðŸ“¦ **Package Design**
- **Single responsibility** per package
- **Small, focused interfaces** - "Accept interfaces, return structs"
- **Internal packages** for non-public code
- **No circular dependencies** - Use interfaces to break cycles
- **Minimal public API** - Export only what's necessary

#### ðŸ§ª **Testing Standards**
- **Table-driven tests** always
- **>80% coverage** target
- **Benchmarks** for performance-critical code
- **Race detector** during development (`go test -race`)
- **Fast tests** - If >5 min, split them
- **Mock external APIs** - Don't let third-party services break tests

### **Current Implementation Status**

#### âœ… **Implemented Components**
1. **clock** - Time abstraction with mock support for deterministic testing
2. **decimal_math** - High-precision financial calculations utilities
3. **errors** - Structured error handling with context wrapping
4. **safego** - Safe goroutine management for 24/7 operations
5. **indicators/common** - Standard technical indicators:
   - RSI (Relative Strength Index)
   - ATR (Average True Range)
   - VWAP (Volume Weighted Average Price)
   - OBV (On-Balance Volume)
   - MFI (Money Flow Index)
   - CMF (Chaikin Money Flow)
   - VROC (Volume Rate of Change)
   - Support/Resistance levels

#### ðŸš§ **Planned Components** (from plan.md)
1. **TimeSeries Package** - Custom OHLCV data management
   - Fixed window for live trading
   - Growing series for backtesting
   - Thread-safe with RWMutex
   - Zero external dependencies

2. **Custom Test Package** - Replace testify to remove yaml.v3 dependency
   - Minimal assertion functions
   - Zero external dependencies
   - Compatible API for easy migration

### **Key Design Decisions**

#### ðŸŽ¯ **Build vs Buy Philosophy**
- **Build custom solutions** when external libraries bring unnecessary dependencies
- **Zero tolerance** for indirect dependencies (e.g., yaml.v3 via testify)
- **Tailored implementations** over generic libraries
- Example: Building custom TimeSeries instead of using heavy external libraries

#### ðŸ”„ **Data Flow Architecture**
1. **Exchange data** â†’ TimeSeries storage
2. **TimeSeries** â†’ Indicator calculations
3. **Indicators** â†’ Strategy signals
4. **Signals** â†’ Risk management
5. **Risk approval** â†’ Order execution
6. **Execution** â†’ Position tracking

### **Code Quality Standards**

#### âœ¨ **Clean Code Practices**
- **Document WHY, not WHAT** in comments
- **Error wrapping** with context: `fmt.Errorf("engine.Start: %w", err)`
- **Sentinel errors** for known conditions
- **Defer cleanup** immediately after resource acquisition
- **Early returns** to reduce nesting
- **Immutable configurations** - Copy-on-write patterns

#### ðŸš« **Anti-Patterns to Avoid**
- Backwards compatibility layers
- Gradual migrations
- Deprecation warnings (just delete it)
- Feature flags for old behavior
- Compatibility shims
- Variant files (_v2, _new, _temp)
- TODO comments for compatibility

### **Performance Considerations**

#### âš¡ **Optimization Strategies**
- **Pre-allocate slices** when size is known
- **sync.Pool** for frequently allocated objects
- **Pointer receivers** for large structs
- **Cache-friendly** data structures
- **Batch operations** for efficiency
- **Profile before optimizing** - Measure, don't guess

### **Development Workflow**

#### ðŸ”§ **Standard Practices**
- Small commits doing one thing
- Never break the build
- Clear commit messages
- Run tests before committing
- Format code with `go fmt`
- Use `go mod tidy` to clean dependencies

#### ðŸ“ **Documentation Requirements**
- Document all exported items with godoc
- Start comments with the name being declared
- Provide usage examples
- Never create documentation unless explicitly requested
- Keep documentation in code, not separate files

### **Security & Reliability**

#### ðŸ”’ **Security Practices**
- Environment variables for configuration
- Never commit secrets
- Input validation and sanitization
- Monthly security updates for dependencies
- Error tracking (Sentry or similar) for production

#### ðŸ›¡ï¸ **Reliability Features**
- Graceful shutdown handling
- Health checks and readiness probes
- Structured logging with context
- Metrics and observability hooks
- Idempotent operations
- Background job deduplication

### **Summary**

Big Meanie represents a clean, performance-focused approach to cryptocurrency trading systems. The codebase emphasizes:
- **Radical simplicity** through breaking changes over compatibility
- **Performance** through Go's concurrency and careful optimization
- **Reliability** through comprehensive testing and error handling
- **Maintainability** through clear structure and minimal dependencies

The system is designed to run 24/7 with high reliability, supporting multiple exchanges and trading strategies while maintaining clean, idiomatic Go code throughout.

Ready to discuss any aspect of the Big Meanie codebase in detail. I've thoroughly studied the documentation and understand:

- The **"Break Fast, Fix Immediately"** philosophy
- **Ultra-concise naming** conventions
- **shopspring/decimal** usage patterns
- **Concurrency patterns** for 24/7 operations
- **Package structure** and current implementation status
- **Testing standards** and quality requirements
- The planned **TimeSeries** and custom **test package** implementations

What would you like to explore or discuss?

toolUseResult.originalFileContents:
# Big Meanie Trading System Development Assistant

## System Overview
Big Meanie will be a 24/7 cryptocurrency trading bot built in Go, designed to leverage Go's concurrency capabilities for maximum performance. The system:

- **Supports multiple cryptocurrency exchanges** for trading operations
- **Handles spot, futures, and perpetual trading** on supported exchanges
- **Provides feature parity** between backtesting and live trading environments
- **Implements custom trading strategies** based on technical indicators
- **Uses decimal precision** (shopspring/decimal) where accuracy matters
- **Maximizes Go concurrency** for parallel processing and 24/7 operations
- **Graceful/Emergency shutdown** handling to stop/resume backtesting or trading features

For detailed information about specific components and usage, see the README.md files located in each directory.

## Agent Delegation

### Specialized Go Agents
- **gad (Go Architecture Decision)**: Use for system design, package structure, interface patterns
- **god (Go Implementation)**: Use for writing, fixing, or refactoring Go code

### When to Delegate
- Architecture questions â†’ gad
- Code implementation â†’ god
- Project management â†’ Main Claude
- Documentation â†’ Main Claude
- Git operations â†’ Main Claude

### Coordination Pattern
1. User requests feature â†’ Delegate to gad for design in plan.md
2. User refines with gad until plan.md design is ready
3. User requests implementation of gad's plan.md:
   - Main Claude syncs tasks with todo.md/TodoWrite
   - Delegate to god to implement gad's design
4. Testing/Integration â†’ Main Claude coordinates

## Project Structure

- **/back**: Backend code - all Go code for trading bot, backtesting, and API integrations
- **/front**: Frontend code - web interface and visualization components

Each directory contains a README.md file explaining its contents and usage.

## Workflow: Plan & Todo

### Reviews and Summaries
**Purpose**: Rolling workspace for planning and discussing ideas or changes. This helps maintain context during discussions and ensures we have a clear, agreed-upon approach before making changes.
- File: plan.md (in /back/.docs/)

**Key Behavior**: When user switches a plan "topic", rename the current plan.md to plan_*.md where * is replaced by an appropriate and concise name.

### Task List
**Purpose**: Maintain a synchronized todo list between Claude's internal TodoWrite tool and the project's todo.md file. This provides real-time visibility of task progress to users even when Claude's terminal display doesn't show the todo list.

- File: todo.md (in /back/.docs/)
- Critical/High/Medium/Low priority tasks
- Completed tasks (temporarily kept for reference)

**Key Behaviors**:
1. **Sync on completion**: After marking a todo as completed using TodoWrite, immediately update todo.md to reflect the completion
2. **Mirror structure**: Ensure todo.md reflects the same task organization as Claude's internal todo list
3. **Real-time updates**: Update todo.md as tasks progress through states (pending â†’ in_progress â†’ completed)
4. **Priority management**: When adding new todos, analyze existing tasks and recommend priority ordering
5. **Conflict resolution**: Review new todos against existing ones to identify potential conflicts or duplicates
6. **Maintenance**: Keep completed tasks in todo.md if they contain information useful for documentation updates. Only remove them after documentation has been updated accordingly
7. **Priority transitions**: Always get user consent before starting tasks of a new priority level. When completing all tasks of one priority (e.g., High), ask the user before moving to the next priority level (e.g., Medium)

## Workflow: Execution
**Purpose**: Maintain clean, consistent code organization.
- Focus on MVP functionality over complex features
- Delegate Go implementation to god agent
- Delegate architecture decisions to gad agent

## Go Development Guidelines

### Key Principles
- shopspring/decimal for ALL numeric operations
- Ultra-concise naming (sr not SupportResistance)
- No backwards compatibility
- Table-driven tests with testify
- Never use t.Skip()

### File Management
- NEVER create variant files (no _v2, _new, _enhanced, _refactored)
- Always update existing files instead of creating alternatives
- Check existing files before creating new ones

## Important Reminders

- NEVER maintain backwards compatibility when making changes
- NEVER refer to "phases" in commit messages
- NEVER include "Co-Authored by" in commit messages
- NEVER commit sensitive data (API keys, passwords)
- NEVER force-add gitignored files
- NEVER proactively create documentation files unless requested
- Push back against bad ideas to make the user question their decision

    15â†’## Package Design
    16â†’
    17â†’### Package Structure

    30â†’â”‚   â””â”€â”€ worker/

    32â†’â”œâ”€â”€ internal/
    33â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ auth/

    67â†’

    99â†’func HashPassword(password string) string { }
   100â†’func SendEmail(to, subject, body string) error { }
   101â†’func ParseJSON(data []byte) (interface{}, error) { }
   102â†’func GenerateID() string { }
   103â†’
   104â†’// Better: specific packages
   105â†’package password
   106â†’package email
   107â†’package json
   108â†’package id

   111â†’### Package Dependencies
   112â†’```go
   113â†’// Minimize dependencies
   114â†’package user
   115â†’
   116â†’// Good: depends only on necessary packages
   117â†’import (
   118â†’    "context"
   119â†’    "myproject/internal/database"
   120â†’)
   121â†’
   122â†’// Bad: too many dependencies
   123â†’import (
   124â†’    "myproject/internal/auth"
   125â†’    "myproject/internal/email"
   126â†’    "myproject/internal/sms"
   127â†’    "myproject/internal/push"
   128â†’    "myproject/internal/analytics"
   129â†’    // ... many more
   130â†’)
   131â†’
   132â†’// Dependency inversion
   133â†’package service
   134â†’
   135â†’// Define interface in the consumer package
   136â†’type UserRepository interface {
   137â†’    GetUser(ctx context.Context, id string) (*User, error)
   138â†’    SaveUser(ctx context.Context, user *User) error
   139â†’}
   140â†’
   141â†’type UserService struct {
   142â†’    repo UserRepository  // Depend on interface
   143â†’}
   144â†’
   145â†’// Implementation in another package
   146â†’package database
   147â†’
   148â†’type PostgresUserRepository struct {
   149â†’    db *sql.DB
   150â†’}
   151â†’
   152â†’func (r *PostgresUserRepository) GetUser(ctx context.Context, id string) (*User, error) {
   153â†’    // Implementation
   154â†’}
   155â†’
   156â†’// Avoid circular dependencies
   157â†’package a
   158â†’import "b"  // a depends on b
   159â†’
   160â†’package b
   161â†’import "a"  // b depends on a - CIRCULAR!
   162â†’
   163â†’// Solution: introduce interface or third package
   164â†’package c
   165â†’type SharedInterface interface { }
   166â†’
   167â†’package a
   168â†’import "c"
   169â†’
   170â†’package b
   171â†’import "c"
   172â†’```

   174â†’## API Design
   175â†’
   176â†’### Exported vs Unexported
   177â†’```go
   178â†’package mypackage
   179â†’
   180â†’// Exported (public) - capitalized
   181â†’type Client struct {
   182â†’    Endpoint string
   183â†’    Timeout  time.Duration
   184â†’}
   185â†’
   186â†’func NewClient(endpoint string) *Client {
   187â†’    return &Client{
   188â†’        Endpoint: endpoint,
   189â†’        Timeout:  30 * time.Second,
   190â†’    }
   191â†’}
   192â†’
   193â†’func (c *Client) Request(ctx context.Context, data []byte) (*Response, error) {
   194â†’    return c.doRequest(ctx, data)
   195â†’}
   196â†’
   197â†’// Unexported (private) - lowercase
   198â†’type config struct {
   199â†’    retryCount int
   200â†’    backoff    time.Duration
   201â†’}
   202â†’
   203â†’func (c *Client) doRequest(ctx context.Context, data []byte) (*Response, error) {
   204â†’    // Internal implementation
   205â†’}
   206â†’
   207â†’// Partially exported struct
   208â†’type Response struct {
   209â†’    Status  int         // Exported
   210â†’    Data    []byte      // Exported
   211â†’    headers http.Header // Unexported
   212â†’}
   213â†’```
   214â†’
   215â†’### API Stability
   216â†’```go
   217â†’// Stable API design
   218â†’package stable
   219â†’
   220â†’// Use interfaces for flexibility
   221â†’type Store interface {
   222â†’    Get(key string) ([]byte, error)
   223â†’    Set(key string, value []byte) error
   224â†’    Delete(key string) error
   225â†’}
   226â†’
   227â†’// Options pattern for extensibility
   228â†’type ClientOptions struct {
   229â†’    Timeout     time.Duration
   230â†’    MaxRetries  int
   231â†’    Headers     map[string]string
   232â†’    // Can add new fields without breaking
   233â†’}
   234â†’
   235â†’func NewClient(opts ClientOptions) *Client {
   236â†’    // Set defaults for zero values
   237â†’    if opts.Timeout == 0 {
   238â†’        opts.Timeout = 30 * time.Second
   239â†’    }
   240â†’    if opts.MaxRetries == 0 {
   241â†’        opts.MaxRetries = 3
   242â†’    }
   243â†’    
   244â†’    return &Client{opts: opts}
   245â†’}
   246â†’
   247â†’// Functional options for better API
   248â†’type Option func(*Client)
   249â†’
   250â†’func WithTimeout(d time.Duration) Option {
   251â†’    return func(c *Client) {
   252â†’        c.timeout = d
   253â†’    }
   254â†’}
   255â†’
   256â†’func WithRetries(n int) Option {
   257â†’    return func(c *Client) {
   258â†’        c.maxRetries = n
   259â†’    }
   260â†’}
   261â†’
   262â†’func NewClientWithOptions(opts ...Option) *Client {
   263â†’    c := &Client{
   264â†’        timeout:    30 * time.Second,
   265â†’        maxRetries: 3,
   266â†’    }
   267â†’    
   268â†’    for _, opt := range opts {
   269â†’        opt(c)
   270â†’    }
   271â†’    
   272â†’    return c
   273â†’}
   274â†’
   275â†’// Deprecation
   276â†’// Deprecated: Use NewClientWithOptions instead.
   277â†’func NewClientOld(endpoint string) *Client {
   278â†’    return NewClientWithOptions(WithEndpoint(endpoint))
   279â†’}
   280â†’```
   281â†’
   282â†’### Error Design
   283â†’```go
   284â†’package mypackage
   285â†’
   286â†’// Sentinel errors
   287â†’var (
   288â†’    ErrNotFound      = errors.New("not found")
   289â†’    ErrUnauthorized  = errors.New("unauthorized")
   290â†’    ErrInvalidInput  = errors.New("invalid input")
   291â†’)
   292â†’
   293â†’// Error types
   294â†’type ValidationError struct {
   295â†’    Field   string
   296â†’    Message string
   297â†’}
   298â†’
   299â†’func (e ValidationError) Error() string {
   300â†’    return fmt.Sprintf("validation error on field %s: %s", e.Field, e.Message)
   301â†’}
   302â†’
   303â†’// Error wrapping
   304â†’func GetUser(id string) (*User, error) {
   305â†’    user, err := db.Query(id)
   306â†’    if err != nil {
   307â†’        if errors.Is(err, sql.ErrNoRows) {
   308â†’            return nil, ErrNotFound
   309â†’        }
   310â†’        return nil, fmt.Errorf("failed to get user %s: %w", id, err)
   311â†’    }
   312â†’    return user, nil
   313â†’}
   314â†’
   315â†’// Custom error checking
   316â†’func IsNotFound(err error) bool {
   317â†’    return errors.Is(err, ErrNotFound)
   318â†’}
   319â†’
   320â†’func IsValidation(err error) bool {
   321â†’    var validationErr ValidationError
   322â†’    return errors.As(err, &validationErr)
   323â†’}
   324â†’```

   373â†’### Internal Best Practices

   416â†’## Versioning
   417â†’
   418â†’### Semantic Versioning
   419â†’```go
   420â†’// go.mod versioning
   421â†’module github.com/user/myproject
   422â†’
   423â†’go 1.21
   424â†’
   425â†’require (
   426â†’    github.com/some/dep v1.2.3   // Exact version
   427â†’    github.com/other/dep v2.0.0+incompatible
   428â†’    github.com/new/dep/v2 v2.1.0 // Major version in path
   429â†’)
   430â†’
   431â†’// Version tags
   432â†’// git tag v1.0.0
   433â†’// git tag v1.0.1
   434â†’// git tag v1.1.0
   435â†’// git tag v2.0.0
   436â†’
   437â†’// Major version changes (v2+)
   438â†’// Update module path
   439â†’module github.com/user/myproject/v2
   440â†’
   441â†’// Import with version
   442â†’import "github.com/user/myproject/v2/pkg/client"
   443â†’
   444â†’// Maintaining multiple versions
   445â†’myproject/
   446â†’â”œâ”€â”€ go.mod          // module github.com/user/myproject
   447â†’â””â”€â”€ v2/
   448â†’    â””â”€â”€ go.mod      // module github.com/user/myproject/v2
   449â†’
   450â†’// Version constraints
   451â†’require (
   452â†’    github.com/some/dep v1.2.3     // Exact
   453â†’    github.com/some/dep v1.2.x     // Patch updates
   454â†’    github.com/some/dep v1.x.x     // Minor updates
   455â†’    github.com/some/dep latest     // Latest
   456â†’    github.com/some/dep master     // Branch
   457â†’)
   458â†’```

   461â†’```go
   462â†’// Package versioning
   463â†’api/
   464â†’â”œâ”€â”€ v1/
   465â†’â”‚   â””â”€â”€ client.go
   466â†’â””â”€â”€ v2/
   467â†’    â””â”€â”€ client.go

   487â†’

   489â†’    // v2 implementation with context

   491â†’
   492â†’// Supporting multiple versions
   493â†’package api
   494â†’
   495â†’import (

   497â†’    v2 "myproject/api/v2"

   511â†’### Package Documentation
   512â†’```go
   513â†’// Package documentation (doc.go)
   514â†’/*
   515â†’Package user provides user management functionality for the application.
   516â†’
   517â†’The package includes:
   518â†’  - User CRUD operations
   519â†’  - Authentication and authorization
   520â†’  - Profile management
   521â†’  - Password reset functionality
   522â†’
   523â†’Basic usage:
   524â†’
   525â†’	service := user.NewService(db)
   526â†’	
   527â†’	// Create user
   528â†’	u, err := service.Create(ctx, user.CreateRequest{
   529â†’		Email:    "user@example.com",
   530â†’		Password: "secure123",
   531â†’	})
   532â†’	
   533â†’	// Authenticate
   534â†’	token, err := service.Authenticate(ctx, email, password)
   535â†’
   536â†’For more examples, see the examples directory.
   537â†’*/
   538â†’package user
   539â†’
   540â†’// Type documentation
   541â†’// User represents a system user.
   542â†’// Users can have multiple roles and permissions.
   543â†’type User struct {
   544â†’    // ID is the unique identifier for the user.
   545â†’    ID string
   546â†’    
   547â†’    // Email is the user's email address.
   548â†’    // It must be unique across all users.
   549â†’    Email string
   550â†’    
   551â†’    // CreatedAt is when the user was created.
   552â†’    CreatedAt time.Time
   553â†’    
   554â†’    // Roles contains the user's assigned roles.
   555â†’    Roles []Role
   556â†’}
   557â†’
   558â†’// Method documentation
   559â†’// Create creates a new user with the given request.
   560â†’// It returns an error if the email already exists or validation fails.
   561â†’//
   562â†’// Example:
   563â†’//
   564â†’//	user, err := service.Create(ctx, CreateRequest{
   565â†’//	    Email:    "user@example.com",
   566â†’//	    Password: "secure123",
   567â†’//	})
   568â†’//	if err != nil {
   569â†’//	    log.Fatal(err)
   570â†’//	}
   571â†’func (s *Service) Create(ctx context.Context, req CreateRequest) (*User, error) {
   572â†’    // Implementation
   573â†’}
   574â†’
   575â†’// Deprecated documentation
   576â†’// Deprecated: Use CreateWithOptions instead.
   577â†’// This function will be removed in v2.0.0.
   578â†’func (s *Service) CreateOld(email, password string) (*User, error) {
   579â†’    return s.CreateWithOptions(CreateOptions{
   580â†’        Email:    email,
   581â†’        Password: password,
   582â†’    })
   583â†’}

   739â†’## Dependencies
   740â†’
   741â†’### Managing Dependencies
   742â†’```go
   743â†’// Adding dependencies
   744â†’// go get github.com/pkg/errors
   745â†’// go get github.com/pkg/errors@v0.9.1
   746â†’// go get github.com/pkg/errors@latest
   747â†’// go get github.com/pkg/errors@master
   748â†’
   749â†’// Updating dependencies
   750â†’// go get -u                    - Update all
   751â†’// go get -u ./...             - Update all in module
   752â†’// go get -u=patch ./...       - Update patch versions
   753â†’// go get -u github.com/pkg/...  - Update specific package
   754â†’
   755â†’// Removing dependencies
   756â†’// go mod tidy                  - Remove unused
   757â†’
   758â†’// Vendoring
   759â†’// go mod vendor               - Create vendor/
   760â†’// go build -mod=vendor        - Build with vendor/
   761â†’
   762â†’// Dependency analysis
   763â†’import "golang.org/x/mod/modfile"
   764â†’
   765â†’func analyzeDependencies() {
   766â†’    data, _ := os.ReadFile("go.mod")
   767â†’    file, _ := modfile.Parse("go.mod", data, nil)
   768â†’    
   769â†’    for _, req := range file.Require {
   770â†’        fmt.Printf("%s: %s\n", req.Mod.Path, req.Mod.Version)
   771â†’    }
   772â†’}
   773â†’
   774â†’// Private dependencies
   775â†’// Set GOPRIVATE environment variable
   776â†’// GOPRIVATE=github.com/company/*
   777â†’
   778â†’// Use .netrc for authentication
   779â†’// machine github.com
   780â†’// login username
   781â†’// password token
   782â†’
   783â†’// Or use SSH
   784â†’// git config --global url."git@github.com:".insteadOf "https://github.com/"
   785â†’```
   786â†’
   787â†’### Dependency Injection
   788â†’```go
   789â†’// Constructor injection
   790â†’type Service struct {
   791â†’    db     Database
   792â†’    cache  Cache
   793â†’    logger Logger
   794â†’}
   795â†’
   796â†’func NewService(db Database, cache Cache, logger Logger) *Service {

   800â†’        logger: logger,
   801â†’    }
   802â†’}
   803â†’
   804â†’// Interface injection
   805â†’type Database interface {

   808â†’
   809â†’type Cache interface {
   810â†’    Get(string) (interface{}, bool)

   813â†’
   814â†’// Wire for dependency injection
   815â†’//go:build wireinject
   816â†’
   817â†’import "github.com/google/wire"

   819â†’func InitializeService() (*Service, error) {

   825â†’    )
   826â†’    return nil, nil
   827â†’}
   828â†’
   829â†’// Provider sets

   834â†’)

   836â†’var ServiceSet = wire.NewSet(

   842â†’
   843â†’## Package Patterns
   844â†’
   845â†’### Plugin Pattern
   846â†’```go
   847â†’// Plugin interface
   848â†’package plugin
   849â†’
   850â†’type Plugin interface {
   851â†’    Name() string
   852â†’    Initialize(config map[string]interface{}) error
   853â†’    Execute(context.Context, interface{}) (interface{}, error)
   854â†’    Shutdown() error
   855â†’}
   856â†’
   857â†’// Registry
   858â†’type Registry struct {
   859â†’    mu      sync.RWMutex
   860â†’    plugins map[string]Plugin
   861â†’}
   862â†’
   863â†’func (r *Registry) Register(p Plugin) {
   864â†’    r.mu.Lock()
   865â†’    defer r.mu.Unlock()
   866â†’    r.plugins[p.Name()] = p
   867â†’}
   868â†’
   869â†’func (r *Registry) Get(name string) (Plugin, bool) {
   870â†’    r.mu.RLock()
   871â†’    defer r.mu.RUnlock()
   872â†’    p, ok := r.plugins[name]
   873â†’    return p, ok
   874â†’}
   875â†’
   876â†’// Plugin implementation
   877â†’package myplugin
   878â†’
   879â†’type MyPlugin struct {
   880â†’    config map[string]interface{}
   881â†’}
   882â†’
   883â†’func (p *MyPlugin) Name() string {
   884â†’    return "my-plugin"
   885â†’}
   886â†’
   887â†’func (p *MyPlugin) Initialize(config map[string]interface{}) error {
   888â†’    p.config = config
   889â†’    return nil
   890â†’}
   891â†’
   892â†’// Auto-registration
   893â†’func init() {
   894â†’    plugin.DefaultRegistry.Register(&MyPlugin{})
   895â†’}
   896â†’```
   897â†’
   898â†’### Provider Pattern
   899â†’```go
   900â†’// Provider interface
   901â†’package provider
   902â†’
   903â†’type StorageProvider interface {
   904â†’    Read(key string) ([]byte, error)
   905â†’    Write(key string, data []byte) error
   906â†’    Delete(key string) error
   907â†’}
   908â†’
   909â†’// Factory
   910â†’type ProviderFactory func(config Config) (StorageProvider, error)
   911â†’
   912â†’var providers = make(map[string]ProviderFactory)
   913â†’
   914â†’func Register(name string, factory ProviderFactory) {
   915â†’    providers[name] = factory
   916â†’}
   917â†’
   918â†’func New(name string, config Config) (StorageProvider, error) {
   919â†’    factory, ok := providers[name]
   920â†’    if !ok {
   921â†’        return nil, fmt.Errorf("unknown provider: %s", name)
   922â†’    }
   923â†’    return factory(config)
   924â†’}
   925â†’
   926â†’// S3 provider
   927â†’package s3
   928â†’
   929â†’func init() {
   930â†’    provider.Register("s3", NewS3Provider)
   931â†’}
   932â†’
   933â†’func NewS3Provider(config provider.Config) (provider.StorageProvider, error) {
   934â†’    return &S3Provider{
   935â†’        bucket: config.Get("bucket"),
   936â†’        region: config.Get("region"),
   937â†’    }, nil
   938â†’}
   939â†’```
   940â†’
   941â†’### Repository Pattern
   942â†’```go
   943â†’package repository
   944â†’
   945â†’// Generic repository interface
   946â†’type Repository[T any] interface {
   947â†’    Find(ctx context.Context, id string) (*T, error)
   948â†’    FindAll(ctx context.Context) ([]*T, error)
   949â†’    Create(ctx context.Context, entity *T) error
   950â†’    Update(ctx context.Context, entity *T) error
   951â†’    Delete(ctx context.Context, id string) error
   952â†’}
   953â†’
   954â†’// Specific implementation
   955â†’type UserRepository interface {
   956â†’    Repository[User]
   957â†’    FindByEmail(ctx context.Context, email string) (*User, error)

   959â†’}
   960â†’
   961â†’// SQL implementation
   962â†’type sqlUserRepository struct {
   963â†’    db *sql.DB
   964â†’}
   965â†’
   966â†’func NewSQLUserRepository(db *sql.DB) UserRepository {

   969â†’
   970â†’func (r *sqlUserRepository) Find(ctx context.Context, id string) (*User, error) {

   972â†’    // Implementation

   979â†’
   980â†’func NewMongoUserRepository(db *mongo.Database) UserRepository {
   981â†’    return &mongoUserRepository{
   982â†’        collection: db.Collection("users"),
   983â†’    }
   984â†’}
   985â†’```

   987â†’## Publishing Packages
   988â†’
   989â†’### Preparing for Publication
   990â†’```go
   991â†’// 1. Choose a good name
   992â†’// - Descriptive and unique
   993â†’// - Avoid generic names (utils, helpers, common)
   994â†’// - Check if name is available
   995â†’
   996â†’// 2. Create comprehensive documentation
   997â†’// - README.md with examples
   998â†’// - Package documentation

  1000â†’// - CONTRIBUTING.md

  1002â†’
  1003â†’// 3. Add examples
  1004â†’examples/
  1005â†’â”œâ”€â”€ basic/
  1006â†’â”‚   â””â”€â”€ main.go

  1017â†’// 5. Set up CI/CD

  1033â†’
  1034â†’### Publishing Process
  1035â†’```bash
  1036â†’# 1. Tag version
  1037â†’git tag v1.0.0
  1038â†’git push origin v1.0.0
  1039â†’
  1040â†’# 2. The package is automatically available

  1047â†’# 4. Add badges to README

  1049â†’[![Go Report Card](https://goreportcard.com/badge/github.com/username/package)](https://goreportcard.com/report/github.com/username/package)
  1050â†’[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/repos/github/username/package/badge.svg)](https://coveralls.io/github/username/package)
  1051â†’
  1052â†’# 5. Create release on GitHub

  1056â†’
  1057â†’### Package Maintenance
  1058â†’```go
  1059â†’// Deprecation process
  1060â†’// 1. Mark as deprecated in documentation
  1061â†’// Deprecated: Use NewFunction instead.
  1062â†’// This will be removed in v2.0.0.
  1063â†’func OldFunction() {}
  1064â†’

  1068â†’    // Existing implementation

  1070â†’
  1071â†’// 3. Provide migration guide

  1073â†’Migration Guide from v1 to v2:
  1074â†’
  1075â†’1. Replace OldFunction() with NewFunction()

  1084â†’// Version compatibility

  1100â†’## Best Practices
  1101â†’
  1102â†’### Package Design Principles
  1103â†’```go
  1104â†’// 1. Single Responsibility

  1107â†’// 2. Minimal Public API

  1109â†’package mypackage

  1111â†’type Client struct{} // Exported

  1115â†’// 3. Accept Interfaces, Return Structs

  1120â†’
  1121â†’// 4. Avoid Init Functions
  1122â†’// Bad: Side effects on import

  1125â†’}
  1126â†’

  1131â†’
  1132â†’// 5. No Circular Dependencies
