input.content:
# Big Meanie Code Review Checklist

## Purpose

This checklist ensures all Go code in the Big Meanie project meets our strict quality standards. Reviewers should go through each section systematically, marking items as âœ“ (pass) or âœ— (fail) with specific comments.

## Pre-Review Verification

### File Management
- [ ] **No variant files created** (no _v2, _new, _enhanced, _refactored variants)
- [ ] **Existing files updated** instead of creating alternatives
- [ ] **No unnecessary documentation files** created unless explicitly requested
- [ ] **Import paths are absolute** (e.g., `bigmeanie/pkg/...` not `../pkg/...`)

### Breaking Changes Philosophy
- [ ] **NO backwards compatibility code** present
- [ ] **NO migration/transition code** between old and new implementations
- [ ] **NO deprecated methods or fields** maintained
- [ ] **NO versioned APIs** (v1, v2) - single version only
- [ ] **NO adapter or compatibility shim patterns**
- [ ] **Clean breaks enforced** - compilation failures force immediate updates

## Go Language Standards

### Naming Conventions
- [ ] **Concise naming used** (e.g., `SR` not `SupportResistance`)
- [ ] **Standard abbreviations followed**:
  - `cfg` not `config`
  - `ctx` not `context`
  - `conn` not `connection`
  - `qty` not `quantity`
  - `vol` not `volume`
  - `pos` not `position`
- [ ] **Method names are short** (`Calc()` not `Calculate()`)
- [ ] **Getters don't use Get prefix** (`Price()` not `GetPrice()`)
- [ ] **Boolean methods use Is/Has/Can** (`IsValid()`, `HasData()`, `CanTrade()`)
- [ ] **Interfaces end with -er** for single methods (`Reader`, `Writer`)
- [ ] **Package names are lowercase, singular** (`http` not `HTTP` or `https`)
- [ ] **No underscores in package names**

### Error Handling
- [ ] **Explicit error checking** with `if err != nil` everywhere
- [ ] **Errors wrapped with context** using `fmt.Errorf("context: %w", err)`
- [ ] **Sentinel errors defined** for known error conditions
- [ ] **No panics in library code** - return errors instead
- [ ] **Defer cleanup immediately after resource acquisition**
- [ ] **Error messages provide actionable context**
- [ ] **Multiple errors handled appropriately** (first error wins or accumulate all)

## Project-Specific Requirements

### Decimal Precision (CRITICAL)
- [ ] **shopspring/decimal used for ALL financial calculations**
- [ ] **NO float64 for money, prices, quantities, or percentages**
- [ ] **Decimal creation from strings** when possible (`RequireFromString`)
- [ ] **Float conversion validated** when interfacing with external APIs
- [ ] **Proper decimal comparisons** (`Equal()`, `LessThan()`, not `==`, `<`)
- [ ] **Zero checks use IsZero()** not comparison with decimal.Zero
- [ ] **Percentage calculations explicit** (divide by 100 when needed)

### Concurrency Patterns
- [ ] **Context used for cancellation** in all long-running operations
- [ ] **Goroutines properly managed** with WaitGroups or channels
- [ ] **No goroutine leaks** - all goroutines can terminate
- [ ] **Loop variable capture handled correctly** in goroutines
- [ ] **Channels properly closed** by sender, checked by receiver
- [ ] **Mutex usage reviewed** for deadlocks and race conditions
- [ ] **Atomic operations used** for simple shared state
- [ ] **Worker pools bounded** to prevent resource exhaustion

### 24/7 Operation Requirements
- [ ] **Graceful shutdown implemented** with context cancellation
- [ ] **Recovery mechanisms in place** for critical goroutines
- [ ] **Resource cleanup in defer blocks**
- [ ] **Connection pooling** for database and API clients
- [ ] **Circuit breakers** for external service calls
- [ ] **Backoff strategies** for retries
- [ ] **Memory leaks prevented** (close channels, cancel contexts)

## Testing Requirements

### Test Coverage
- [ ] **Table-driven tests used** for multiple test cases
- [ ] **Edge cases tested** (zero values, nil, empty, boundaries)
- [ ] **Error conditions tested** explicitly
- [ ] **NO t.Skip() used** - fix or delete broken tests
- [ ] **Subtests with t.Run()** for organization
- [ ] **Test helpers marked** with `t.Helper()`
- [ ] **Parallel tests marked** with `t.Parallel()` where safe

### Test Quality
- [ ] **Tests are deterministic** - no flaky tests
- [ ] **External dependencies mocked** (APIs, databases)
- [ ] **Test data uses decimals** for financial values
- [ ] **Benchmarks provided** for performance-critical code
- [ ] **Example tests included** for documentation
- [ ] **Integration tests** for API endpoints
- [ ] **Tests run fast** (< 5 minutes for full suite)

## Performance Considerations

### Memory Efficiency
- [ ] **Slices preallocated** when size is known
- [ ] **Pointer receivers** for large structs
- [ ] **sync.Pool used** for frequently allocated objects
- [ ] **strings.Builder** for string concatenation in loops
- [ ] **bytes.Buffer** preferred over string concatenation
- [ ] **No unnecessary copying** in loops

### Optimization
- [ ] **Hot paths identified and optimized**
- [ ] **Benchmarks verify optimizations**
- [ ] **Allocations minimized** in critical paths
- [ ] **Interface allocations avoided** where possible
- [ ] **Reflection avoided** in performance-critical code
- [ ] **Map capacity set** when size is known

## Security & Validation

### Input Validation
- [ ] **All user input sanitized** before use
- [ ] **Bounds checking** on array/slice access
- [ ] **SQL injection prevented** (parameterized queries)
- [ ] **Integer overflow checked** for financial calculations
- [ ] **Division by zero handled** with decimal operations

### API Security
- [ ] **Authentication required** for protected endpoints
- [ ] **Rate limiting implemented** for public endpoints
- [ ] **CORS configured properly** for web access
- [ ] **Sensitive data not logged** (API keys, passwords)
- [ ] **TLS/HTTPS enforced** for production

### Configuration
- [ ] **Secrets from environment variables** not hardcoded
- [ ] **No sensitive data in git** (.env in .gitignore)
- [ ] **Configuration validated** on startup
- [ ] **Defaults are safe** (fail closed, not open)

## Documentation Standards

### Code Documentation
- [ ] **Package comments explain purpose** not just name
- [ ] **Exported types and functions documented**
- [ ] **Comments explain WHY** not WHAT
- [ ] **Edge cases documented** in comments
- [ ] **Assumptions stated explicitly**
- [ ] **TODO comments actionable** (no vague TODOs)
- [ ] **NO compatibility TODO comments** ("remove after migration")

### API Documentation
- [ ] **REST endpoints documented** with request/response examples
- [ ] **WebSocket protocol documented** with message formats
- [ ] **Error responses documented** with status codes
- [ ] **Rate limits documented** clearly

## Code Organization

### Package Structure
- [ ] **Single responsibility** per package
- [ ] **Interfaces small and focused** (1-3 methods ideal)
- [ ] **Interfaces defined at usage point** not with implementation
- [ ] **Standard library interfaces** used when applicable
- [ ] **Circular dependencies avoided**

### Design Patterns
- [ ] **Composition over inheritance** used
- [ ] **"Accept interfaces, return structs"** pattern followed
- [ ] **Synchronous by default** - let callers handle concurrency
- [ ] **Minimal abstractions** - obvious solutions preferred
- [ ] **DRY principle** - repeated code extracted
- [ ] **YAGNI principle** - no speculative features

## Final Checks

### Critical Standards
- [ ] **All financial math uses decimal** - NO EXCEPTIONS
- [ ] **No backwards compatibility** - NO EXCEPTIONS
- [ ] **All tests pass** - NO SKIPPED TESTS
- [ ] **Clean git history** - no "Generated with Claude" messages
- [ ] **go fmt applied** to all files
- [ ] **go vet passes** without warnings
- [ ] **Race detector clean** (`go test -race`)

### Performance Verification
- [ ] **Benchmarks show acceptable performance**
- [ ] **Memory usage profiled** for leaks
- [ ] **CPU profile shows** no obvious bottlenecks
- [ ] **Graceful degradation** under load

## Review Sign-off

**Reviewer**: _______________  
**Date**: _______________  
**Status**: [ ] APPROVED [ ] NEEDS CHANGES [ ] REJECTED

### Required for Approval
1. All CRITICAL items must pass
2. No backwards compatibility code present
3. All financial calculations use decimal
4. All tests pass without skips
5. Clean breaks enforced throughout

### Comments
```
[Specific issues requiring fixes]
```

---

## Quick Reference

### Commands to Run Before Review
```bash
# Format check
go fmt ./...

# Vet check
go vet ./...

# Test with race detector
go test -race ./...

# Test coverage
go test -cover ./...

# Benchmark performance
go test -bench=. ./...

# Check for decimal usage in financial code
grep -r "float64\|float32" --include="*.go" | grep -E "(price|amount|quantity|fee|balance|pnl)"
```

### Red Flags - Immediate Rejection

7. Concise, clear naming

# Big Meanie Code Review Checklist

## Purpose

This checklist ensures all Go code in the Big Meanie project meets our strict quality standards. Reviewers should go through each section systematically, marking items as âœ“ (pass) or âœ— (fail) with specific comments.

## Pre-Review Verification

### File Management
- [ ] **No variant files created** (no _v2, _new, _enhanced, _refactored variants)
- [ ] **Existing files updated** instead of creating alternatives
- [ ] **No unnecessary documentation files** created unless explicitly requested
- [ ] **Import paths are absolute** (e.g., `bigmeanie/pkg/...` not `../pkg/...`)

### Breaking Changes Philosophy
- [ ] **NO backwards compatibility code** present
- [ ] **NO migration/transition code** between old and new implementations
- [ ] **NO deprecated methods or fields** maintained
- [ ] **NO versioned APIs** (v1, v2) - single version only
- [ ] **NO adapter or compatibility shim patterns**
- [ ] **Clean breaks enforced** - compilation failures force immediate updates

## Go Language Standards

### Naming Conventions
- [ ] **Concise naming used** (e.g., `SR` not `SupportResistance`)
- [ ] **Standard abbreviations followed**:
  - `cfg` not `config`
  - `ctx` not `context`
  - `conn` not `connection`
  - `qty` not `quantity`
  - `vol` not `volume`
  - `pos` not `position`
- [ ] **Method names are short** (`Calc()` not `Calculate()`)
- [ ] **Getters don't use Get prefix** (`Price()` not `GetPrice()`)
- [ ] **Boolean methods use Is/Has/Can** (`IsValid()`, `HasData()`, `CanTrade()`)
- [ ] **Interfaces end with -er** for single methods (`Reader`, `Writer`)
- [ ] **Package names are lowercase, singular** (`http` not `HTTP` or `https`)
- [ ] **No underscores in package names**

### Error Handling
- [ ] **Explicit error checking** with `if err != nil` everywhere
- [ ] **Errors wrapped with context** using `fmt.Errorf("context: %w", err)`
- [ ] **Sentinel errors defined** for known error conditions
- [ ] **No panics in library code** - return errors instead
- [ ] **Defer cleanup immediately after resource acquisition**
- [ ] **Error messages provide actionable context**
- [ ] **Multiple errors handled appropriately** (first error wins or accumulate all)

## Project-Specific Requirements

### Decimal Precision (CRITICAL)
- [ ] **shopspring/decimal used for ALL financial calculations**
- [ ] **NO float64 for money, prices, quantities, or percentages**
- [ ] **Decimal creation from strings** when possible (`RequireFromString`)
- [ ] **Float conversion validated** when interfacing with external APIs
- [ ] **Proper decimal comparisons** (`Equal()`, `LessThan()`, not `==`, `<`)
- [ ] **Zero checks use IsZero()** not comparison with decimal.Zero
- [ ] **Percentage calculations explicit** (divide by 100 when needed)

### Concurrency Patterns
- [ ] **Context used for cancellation** in all long-running operations
- [ ] **Goroutines properly managed** with WaitGroups or channels
- [ ] **No goroutine leaks** - all goroutines can terminate
- [ ] **Loop variable capture handled correctly** in goroutines
- [ ] **Channels properly closed** by sender, checked by receiver
- [ ] **Mutex usage reviewed** for deadlocks and race conditions
- [ ] **Atomic operations used** for simple shared state
- [ ] **Worker pools bounded** to prevent resource exhaustion

### 24/7 Operation Requirements
- [ ] **Graceful shutdown implemented** with context cancellation
- [ ] **Recovery mechanisms in place** for critical goroutines
- [ ] **Resource cleanup in defer blocks**
- [ ] **Connection pooling** for database and API clients
- [ ] **Circuit breakers** for external service calls
- [ ] **Backoff strategies** for retries
- [ ] **Memory leaks prevented** (close channels, cancel contexts)

## Testing Requirements

### Test Coverage
- [ ] **Table-driven tests used** for multiple test cases
- [ ] **Edge cases tested** (zero values, nil, empty, boundaries)
- [ ] **Error conditions tested** explicitly
- [ ] **NO t.Skip() used** - fix or delete broken tests
- [ ] **Subtests with t.Run()** for organization
- [ ] **Test helpers marked** with `t.Helper()`
- [ ] **Parallel tests marked** with `t.Parallel()` where safe

### Test Quality
- [ ] **Tests are deterministic** - no flaky tests
- [ ] **External dependencies mocked** (APIs, databases)
- [ ] **Test data uses decimals** for financial values
- [ ] **Benchmarks provided** for performance-critical code
- [ ] **Example tests included** for documentation
- [ ] **Integration tests** for API endpoints
- [ ] **Tests run fast** (< 5 minutes for full suite)

## Performance Considerations

### Memory Efficiency
- [ ] **Slices preallocated** when size is known
- [ ] **Pointer receivers** for large structs
- [ ] **sync.Pool used** for frequently allocated objects
- [ ] **strings.Builder** for string concatenation in loops
- [ ] **bytes.Buffer** preferred over string concatenation
- [ ] **No unnecessary copying** in loops

### Optimization
- [ ] **Hot paths identified and optimized**
- [ ] **Benchmarks verify optimizations**
- [ ] **Allocations minimized** in critical paths
- [ ] **Interface allocations avoided** where possible
- [ ] **Reflection avoided** in performance-critical code
- [ ] **Map capacity set** when size is known

## Security & Validation

### Input Validation
- [ ] **All user input sanitized** before use
- [ ] **Bounds checking** on array/slice access
- [ ] **SQL injection prevented** (parameterized queries)
- [ ] **Integer overflow checked** for financial calculations
- [ ] **Division by zero handled** with decimal operations

### API Security
- [ ] **Authentication required** for protected endpoints
- [ ] **Rate limiting implemented** for public endpoints
- [ ] **CORS configured properly** for web access
- [ ] **Sensitive data not logged** (API keys, passwords)
- [ ] **TLS/HTTPS enforced** for production

### Configuration
- [ ] **Secrets from environment variables** not hardcoded
- [ ] **No sensitive data in git** (.env in .gitignore)
- [ ] **Configuration validated** on startup
- [ ] **Defaults are safe** (fail closed, not open)

## Documentation Standards

### Code Documentation
- [ ] **Package comments explain purpose** not just name
- [ ] **Exported types and functions documented**
- [ ] **Comments explain WHY** not WHAT
- [ ] **Edge cases documented** in comments
- [ ] **Assumptions stated explicitly**
- [ ] **TODO comments actionable** (no vague TODOs)
- [ ] **NO compatibility TODO comments** ("remove after migration")

### API Documentation
- [ ] **REST endpoints documented** with request/response examples
- [ ] **WebSocket protocol documented** with message formats
- [ ] **Error responses documented** with status codes
- [ ] **Rate limits documented** clearly

## Code Organization

### Package Structure
- [ ] **Single responsibility** per package
- [ ] **Interfaces small and focused** (1-3 methods ideal)
- [ ] **Interfaces defined at usage point** not with implementation
- [ ] **Standard library interfaces** used when applicable
- [ ] **Circular dependencies avoided**

### Design Patterns
- [ ] **Composition over inheritance** used
- [ ] **"Accept interfaces, return structs"** pattern followed
- [ ] **Synchronous by default** - let callers handle concurrency
- [ ] **Minimal abstractions** - obvious solutions preferred
- [ ] **DRY principle** - repeated code extracted
- [ ] **YAGNI principle** - no speculative features

## Final Checks

### Critical Standards
- [ ] **All financial math uses decimal** - NO EXCEPTIONS
- [ ] **No backwards compatibility** - NO EXCEPTIONS
- [ ] **All tests pass** - NO SKIPPED TESTS
- [ ] **Clean git history** - no "Generated with Claude" messages
- [ ] **go fmt applied** to all files
- [ ] **go vet passes** without warnings
- [ ] **Race detector clean** (`go test -race`)

### Performance Verification
- [ ] **Benchmarks show acceptable performance**
- [ ] **Memory usage profiled** for leaks
- [ ] **CPU profile shows** no obvious bottlenecks
- [ ] **Graceful degradation** under load

## Review Sign-off

**Reviewer**: _______________  
**Date**: _______________  
**Status**: [ ] APPROVED [ ] NEEDS CHANGES [ ] REJECTED

### Required for Approval
1. All CRITICAL items must pass
2. No backwards compatibility code present
3. All financial calculations use decimal
4. All tests pass without skips
5. Clean breaks enforced throughout

### Comments
```
[Specific issues requiring fixes]
```

---

## Quick Reference

### Commands to Run Before Review
```bash
# Format check
go fmt ./...

# Vet check
go vet ./...

# Test with race detector
go test -race ./...

# Test coverage
go test -cover ./...

# Benchmark performance
go test -bench=. ./...

# Check for decimal usage in financial code
grep -r "float64\|float32" --include="*.go" | grep -E "(price|amount|quantity|fee|balance|pnl)"
```

### Red Flags - Immediate Rejection
1. `float64` used for money/prices
2. `_v2.go` or similar variant files
3. `Deprecated:` comments
4. `TODO: remove after migration`
5. `if useOldVersion {`
6. `t.Skip()` in tests
7. Backwards compatibility adapters
8. Version-specific API endpoints (/v1, /v2)

### Green Flags - Good Patterns
1. `decimal.Decimal` for all financial values
2. Clean, direct error returns
3. Table-driven tests with subtests
4. Context cancellation handled
5. Resources cleaned up with defer
6. Breaking changes that force compilation failures
7. Concise, clear naming
8. Comprehensive error wrapping

file.content:
# Big Meanie Code Review Checklist

## Purpose

This checklist ensures all Go code in the Big Meanie project meets our strict quality standards. Reviewers should go through each section systematically, marking items as âœ“ (pass) or âœ— (fail) with specific comments.

## Pre-Review Verification

### File Management
- [ ] **No variant files created** (no _v2, _new, _enhanced, _refactored variants)
- [ ] **Existing files updated** instead of creating alternatives
- [ ] **No unnecessary documentation files** created unless explicitly requested
- [ ] **Import paths are absolute** (e.g., `bigmeanie/pkg/...` not `../pkg/...`)

### Breaking Changes Philosophy
- [ ] **NO backwards compatibility code** present
- [ ] **NO migration/transition code** between old and new implementations
- [ ] **NO deprecated methods or fields** maintained
- [ ] **NO versioned APIs** (v1, v2) - single version only
- [ ] **NO adapter or compatibility shim patterns**
- [ ] **Clean breaks enforced** - compilation failures force immediate updates

## Go Language Standards

### Naming Conventions
- [ ] **Concise naming used** (e.g., `SR` not `SupportResistance`)
- [ ] **Standard abbreviations followed**:
  - `cfg` not `config`
  - `ctx` not `context`
  - `conn` not `connection`
  - `qty` not `quantity`
  - `vol` not `volume`
  - `pos` not `position`
- [ ] **Method names are short** (`Calc()` not `Calculate()`)
- [ ] **Getters don't use Get prefix** (`Price()` not `GetPrice()`)
- [ ] **Boolean methods use Is/Has/Can** (`IsValid()`, `HasData()`, `CanTrade()`)
- [ ] **Interfaces end with -er** for single methods (`Reader`, `Writer`)
- [ ] **Package names are lowercase, singular** (`http` not `HTTP` or `https`)
- [ ] **No underscores in package names**

### Error Handling
- [ ] **Explicit error checking** with `if err != nil` everywhere
- [ ] **Errors wrapped with context** using `fmt.Errorf("context: %w", err)`
- [ ] **Sentinel errors defined** for known error conditions
- [ ] **No panics in library code** - return errors instead
- [ ] **Defer cleanup immediately after resource acquisition**
- [ ] **Error messages provide actionable context**
- [ ] **Multiple errors handled appropriately** (first error wins or accumulate all)

## Project-Specific Requirements

### Decimal Precision (CRITICAL)
- [ ] **shopspring/decimal used for ALL financial calculations**
- [ ] **NO float64 for money, prices, quantities, or percentages**
- [ ] **Decimal creation from strings** when possible (`RequireFromString`)
- [ ] **Float conversion validated** when interfacing with external APIs
- [ ] **Proper decimal comparisons** (`Equal()`, `LessThan()`, not `==`, `<`)
- [ ] **Zero checks use IsZero()** not comparison with decimal.Zero
- [ ] **Percentage calculations explicit** (divide by 100 when needed)

### Concurrency Patterns
- [ ] **Context used for cancellation** in all long-running operations
- [ ] **Goroutines properly managed** with WaitGroups or channels
- [ ] **No goroutine leaks** - all goroutines can terminate
- [ ] **Loop variable capture handled correctly** in goroutines
- [ ] **Channels properly closed** by sender, checked by receiver
- [ ] **Mutex usage reviewed** for deadlocks and race conditions
- [ ] **Atomic operations used** for simple shared state
- [ ] **Worker pools bounded** to prevent resource exhaustion

### 24/7 Operation Requirements
- [ ] **Graceful shutdown implemented** with context cancellation
- [ ] **Recovery mechanisms in place** for critical goroutines
- [ ] **Resource cleanup in defer blocks**
- [ ] **Connection pooling** for database and API clients
- [ ] **Circuit breakers** for external service calls
- [ ] **Backoff strategies** for retries
- [ ] **Memory leaks prevented** (close channels, cancel contexts)

## Testing Requirements

### Test Coverage
- [ ] **Table-driven tests used** for multiple test cases
- [ ] **Edge cases tested** (zero values, nil, empty, boundaries)
- [ ] **Error conditions tested** explicitly
- [ ] **NO t.Skip() used** - fix or delete broken tests
- [ ] **Subtests with t.Run()** for organization
- [ ] **Test helpers marked** with `t.Helper()`
- [ ] **Parallel tests marked** with `t.Parallel()` where safe

### Test Quality
- [ ] **Tests are deterministic** - no flaky tests
- [ ] **External dependencies mocked** (APIs, databases)
- [ ] **Test data uses decimals** for financial values
- [ ] **Benchmarks provided** for performance-critical code
- [ ] **Example tests included** for documentation
- [ ] **Integration tests** for API endpoints
- [ ] **Tests run fast** (< 5 minutes for full suite)

## Performance Considerations

### Memory Efficiency
- [ ] **Slices preallocated** when size is known
- [ ] **Pointer receivers** for large structs
- [ ] **sync.Pool used** for frequently allocated objects
- [ ] **strings.Builder** for string concatenation in loops
- [ ] **bytes.Buffer** preferred over string concatenation
- [ ] **No unnecessary copying** in loops

### Optimization
- [ ] **Hot paths identified and optimized**
- [ ] **Benchmarks verify optimizations**
- [ ] **Allocations minimized** in critical paths
- [ ] **Interface allocations avoided** where possible
- [ ] **Reflection avoided** in performance-critical code
- [ ] **Map capacity set** when size is known

## Security & Validation

### Input Validation
- [ ] **All user input sanitized** before use
- [ ] **Bounds checking** on array/slice access
- [ ] **SQL injection prevented** (parameterized queries)
- [ ] **Integer overflow checked** for financial calculations
- [ ] **Division by zero handled** with decimal operations

### API Security
- [ ] **Authentication required** for protected endpoints
- [ ] **Rate limiting implemented** for public endpoints
- [ ] **CORS configured properly** for web access
- [ ] **Sensitive data not logged** (API keys, passwords)
- [ ] **TLS/HTTPS enforced** for production

### Configuration
- [ ] **Secrets from environment variables** not hardcoded
- [ ] **No sensitive data in git** (.env in .gitignore)
- [ ] **Configuration validated** on startup
- [ ] **Defaults are safe** (fail closed, not open)

## Documentation Standards

### Code Documentation
- [ ] **Package comments explain purpose** not just name
- [ ] **Exported types and functions documented**
- [ ] **Comments explain WHY** not WHAT
- [ ] **Edge cases documented** in comments
- [ ] **Assumptions stated explicitly**
- [ ] **TODO comments actionable** (no vague TODOs)
- [ ] **NO compatibility TODO comments** ("remove after migration")

### API Documentation
- [ ] **REST endpoints documented** with request/response examples
- [ ] **WebSocket protocol documented** with message formats
- [ ] **Error responses documented** with status codes
- [ ] **Rate limits documented** clearly

## Code Organization

### Package Structure
- [ ] **Single responsibility** per package
- [ ] **Interfaces small and focused** (1-3 methods ideal)
- [ ] **Interfaces defined at usage point** not with implementation
- [ ] **Standard library interfaces** used when applicable
- [ ] **Circular dependencies avoided**

### Design Patterns
- [ ] **Composition over inheritance** used
- [ ] **"Accept interfaces, return structs"** pattern followed
- [ ] **Synchronous by default** - let callers handle concurrency
- [ ] **Minimal abstractions** - obvious solutions preferred
- [ ] **DRY principle** - repeated code extracted
- [ ] **YAGNI principle** - no speculative features

## Final Checks

### Critical Standards
- [ ] **All financial math uses decimal** - NO EXCEPTIONS
- [ ] **No backwards compatibility** - NO EXCEPTIONS
- [ ] **All tests pass** - NO SKIPPED TESTS
- [ ] **Clean git history** - no "Generated with Claude" messages
- [ ] **go fmt applied** to all files
- [ ] **go vet passes** without warnings
- [ ] **Race detector clean** (`go test -race`)

### Performance Verification
- [ ] **Benchmarks show acceptable performance**
- [ ] **Memory usage profiled** for leaks
- [ ] **CPU profile shows** no obvious bottlenecks
- [ ] **Graceful degradation** under load

## Review Sign-off

**Reviewer**: _______________  
**Date**: _______________  
**Status**: [ ] APPROVED [ ] NEEDS CHANGES [ ] REJECTED

### Required for Approval
1. All CRITICAL items must pass
2. No backwards compatibility code present
3. All financial calculations use decimal
4. All tests pass without skips
5. Clean breaks enforced throughout

### Comments
```
[Specific issues requiring fixes]
```

---

## Quick Reference

### Commands to Run Before Review
```bash
# Format check
go fmt ./...

# Vet check
go vet ./...

# Test with race detector
go test -race ./...

# Test coverage
go test -cover ./...

# Benchmark performance
go test -bench=. ./...

# Check for decimal usage in financial code
grep -r "float64\|float32" --include="*.go" | grep -E "(price|amount|quantity|fee|balance|pnl)"
```

### Red Flags - Immediate Rejection
1. `float64` used for money/prices
2. `_v2.go` or similar variant files
3. `Deprecated:` comments
4. `TODO: remove after migration`
5. `if useOldVersion {`
6. `t.Skip()` in tests
7. Backwards compatibility adapters
8. Version-specific API endpoints (/v1, /v2)

### Green Flags - Good Patterns
1. `decimal.Decimal` for all financial values
2. Clean, direct error returns
3. Table-driven tests with subtests
4. Context cancellation handled
5. Resources cleaned up with defer
6. Breaking changes that force compilation failures
7. Concise, clear naming
8. Comprehensive error wrapping

## Analysis Complete

Based on my analysis of the Big Meanie codebase, here are my findings and recommendations:

### Magic Numbers Found

I've identified several instances of magic numbers in the codebase:

1. **Time durations** - hardcoded values like `100 * time.Millisecond`, `30 * time.Second`
2. **Trading thresholds** - values like `0.7`, `0.3` for body ratios in technical analysis
3. **Test data** - values like `100`, `1000` used in tests
4. **Buffer/capacity sizes** - `4096` for stack size, `100`, `1000` for timeseries capacity
5. **Mathematical ratios** - `2.0` for multipliers, `0.5` for splits

### Recommendation

**YES, we should add a "no magic numbers" rule to review.md**, but with **pragmatic exceptions** that fit the Big Meanie philosophy.

### Proposed Addition to review.md

I recommend adding a new section after "Naming Conventions" (around line 40):

```markdown
### Magic Numbers and Constants
- [ ] **Named constants for business logic** (thresholds, ratios, limits)
- [ ] **Time durations use named constants** (`defaultTimeout`, not `30 * time.Second`)
- [ ] **Buffer sizes use named constants** (`maxStackSize`, not `4096`)
- [ ] **Domain-specific values documented** (e.g., `bodyRatioThreshold = 0.7 // Industry standard`)
- [ ] **Exceptions allowed for:**
  - Array indices (0, -1)
  - Percentage conversions (100, 0.01)
  - Binary operations (2, powers of 2)
  - Test data values (unless reused)
  - Single-use time.Duration in tests
```

### Should We Create constants-patterns.md?

**NO**, I don't recommend creating a separate `constants-patterns.md` file. Here's why:

1. **Big Meanie philosophy** - Keep it simple, don't over-document
2. **Existing coverage** - The review checklist addition is sufficient
3. **YAGNI principle** - Don't create documentation "just in case"
4. **Conciseness** - The rule fits well in the existing review.md

### Specific Guidance

**When to use constants:**
- Business logic thresholds (e.g., `const highBodyRatio = decimal.NewFromFloat(0.7)`)
- Repeated time durations (e.g., `const defaultBackoffDelay = 100 * time.Millisecond`)
- API limits (e.g., `const maxRetries = 3`)
- Buffer/capacity sizes (e.g., `const defaultCapacity = 1000`)

**When inline numbers are OK:**
- Array indices (0, -1)
- Mathematical identities (1, 0, 2 for doubling)
- One-off test values
- Percentage math (100, 0.01)
- Time units in tests (1 * time.Second)

### Specific Files Needing Updates

If we add this rule, these files would benefit from constants:

1. `/back/pkg/indicators/vol_delta/approximators.go` - Body ratio thresholds (0.3, 0.7)
2. `/back/pkg/safego/safe.go` - Default backoff parameters
3. `/back/pkg/errors/errors.go` - Already good! Uses `const maxStackSize = 4096`

### Summary

Add the rule to `review.md` but keep it pragmatic. The Big Meanie project values clarity and simplicity over pedantic rules. Named constants should improve readability, not add bureaucracy. The existing `review.md` is the right place for this guidance - no need for a separate file.

- Repeated time durations (e.g., `const defaultBackoffDelay = 100 * time.Millisecond`)
- API limits (e.g., `const maxRetries = 3`)
- Buffer/capacity sizes (e.g., `const defaultCapacity = 1000`)

**When inline numbers are OK:**
- Array indices (0, -1)
- Mathematical identities (1, 0, 2 for doubling)
- One-off test values
- Percentage math (100, 0.01)
- Time units in tests (1 * time.Second)

### Specific Files Needing Updates

If we add this rule, these files would benefit from constants:

1. `/back/pkg/indicators/vol_delta/approximators.go` - Body ratio thresholds (0.3, 0.7)
2. `/back/pkg/safego/safe.go` - Default backoff parameters
3. `/back/pkg/errors/errors.go` - Already good! Uses `const maxStackSize = 4096`

### Summary

Add the rule to `review.md` but keep it pragmatic. The Big Meanie project values clarity and simplicity over pedantic rules. Named constants should improve readability, not add bureaucracy. The existing `review.md` is the right place for this guidance - no need for a separate file.

# Big Meanie Code Review Checklist

## Purpose

This checklist ensures all Go code in the Big Meanie project meets our strict quality standards. Reviewers should go through each section systematically, marking items as âœ“ (pass) or âœ— (fail) with specific comments.

## Pre-Review Verification

### File Management
- [ ] **No variant files created** (no _v2, _new, _enhanced, _refactored variants)
- [ ] **Existing files updated** instead of creating alternatives
- [ ] **No unnecessary documentation files** created unless explicitly requested
- [ ] **Import paths are absolute** (e.g., `bigmeanie/pkg/...` not `../pkg/...`)

### Breaking Changes Philosophy
- [ ] **NO backwards compatibility code** present
- [ ] **NO migration/transition code** between old and new implementations
- [ ] **NO deprecated methods or fields** maintained
- [ ] **NO versioned APIs** (v1, v2) - single version only
- [ ] **NO adapter or compatibility shim patterns**
- [ ] **Clean breaks enforced** - compilation failures force immediate updates

## Go Language Standards

### Naming Conventions
- [ ] **Concise naming used** (e.g., `SR` not `SupportResistance`)
- [ ] **Standard abbreviations followed**:
  - `cfg` not `config`
  - `ctx` not `context`
  - `conn` not `connection`
  - `qty` not `quantity`
  - `vol` not `volume`
  - `pos` not `position`
- [ ] **Method names are short** (`Calc()` not `Calculate()`)
- [ ] **Getters don't use Get prefix** (`Price()` not `GetPrice()`)
- [ ] **Boolean methods use Is/Has/Can** (`IsValid()`, `HasData()`, `CanTrade()`)
- [ ] **Interfaces end with -er** for single methods (`Reader`, `Writer`)
- [ ] **Package names are lowercase, singular** (`http` not `HTTP` or `https`)
- [ ] **No underscores in package names**

### Error Handling
- [ ] **Explicit error checking** with `if err != nil` everywhere
- [ ] **Errors wrapped with context** using `fmt.Errorf("context: %w", err)`
- [ ] **Sentinel errors defined** for known error conditions
- [ ] **No panics in library code** - return errors instead
- [ ] **Defer cleanup immediately after resource acquisition**
- [ ] **Error messages provide actionable context**
- [ ] **Multiple errors handled appropriately** (first error wins or accumulate all)

## Project-Specific Requirements

### Decimal Precision (CRITICAL)
- [ ] **shopspring/decimal used for ALL financial calculations**
- [ ] **NO float64 for money, prices, quantities, or percentages**
- [ ] **Decimal creation from strings** when possible (`RequireFromString`)
- [ ] **Float conversion validated** when interfacing with external APIs
- [ ] **Proper decimal comparisons** (`Equal()`, `LessThan()`, not `==`, `<`)
- [ ] **Zero checks use IsZero()** not comparison with decimal.Zero
- [ ] **Percentage calculations explicit** (divide by 100 when needed)

### Concurrency Patterns
- [ ] **Context used for cancellation** in all long-running operations
- [ ] **Goroutines properly managed** with WaitGroups or channels
- [ ] **No goroutine leaks** - all goroutines can terminate
- [ ] **Loop variable capture handled correctly** in goroutines
- [ ] **Channels properly closed** by sender, checked by receiver
- [ ] **Mutex usage reviewed** for deadlocks and race conditions
- [ ] **Atomic operations used** for simple shared state
- [ ] **Worker pools bounded** to prevent resource exhaustion

### 24/7 Operation Requirements
- [ ] **Graceful shutdown implemented** with context cancellation
- [ ] **Recovery mechanisms in place** for critical goroutines
- [ ] **Resource cleanup in defer blocks**
- [ ] **Connection pooling** for database and API clients
- [ ] **Circuit breakers** for external service calls
- [ ] **Backoff strategies** for retries
- [ ] **Memory leaks prevented** (close channels, cancel contexts)

## Testing Requirements

### Test Coverage
- [ ] **Table-driven tests used** for multiple test cases
- [ ] **Edge cases tested** (zero values, nil, empty, boundaries)
- [ ] **Error conditions tested** explicitly
- [ ] **NO t.Skip() used** - fix or delete broken tests
- [ ] **Subtests with t.Run()** for organization
- [ ] **Test helpers marked** with `t.Helper()`
- [ ] **Parallel tests marked** with `t.Parallel()` where safe

### Test Quality
- [ ] **Tests are deterministic** - no flaky tests
- [ ] **External dependencies mocked** (APIs, databases)
- [ ] **Test data uses decimals** for financial values
- [ ] **Benchmarks provided** for performance-critical code
- [ ] **Example tests included** for documentation
- [ ] **Integration tests** for API endpoints
- [ ] **Tests run fast** (< 5 minutes for full suite)

## Performance Considerations

### Memory Efficiency
- [ ] **Slices preallocated** when size is known
- [ ] **Pointer receivers** for large structs
- [ ] **sync.Pool used** for frequently allocated objects
- [ ] **strings.Builder** for string concatenation in loops
- [ ] **bytes.Buffer** preferred over string concatenation
- [ ] **No unnecessary copying** in loops

### Optimization
- [ ] **Hot paths identified and optimized**
- [ ] **Benchmarks verify optimizations**
- [ ] **Allocations minimized** in critical paths
- [ ] **Interface allocations avoided** where possible
- [ ] **Reflection avoided** in performance-critical code
- [ ] **Map capacity set** when size is known

## Security & Validation

### Input Validation
- [ ] **All user input sanitized** before use
- [ ] **Bounds checking** on array/slice access
- [ ] **SQL injection prevented** (parameterized queries)
- [ ] **Integer overflow checked** for financial calculations
- [ ] **Division by zero handled** with decimal operations

### API Security
- [ ] **Authentication required** for protected endpoints
- [ ] **Rate limiting implemented** for public endpoints
- [ ] **CORS configured properly** for web access
- [ ] **Sensitive data not logged** (API keys, passwords)
- [ ] **TLS/HTTPS enforced** for production

### Configuration
- [ ] **Secrets from environment variables** not hardcoded
- [ ] **No sensitive data in git** (.env in .gitignore)
- [ ] **Configuration validated** on startup
- [ ] **Defaults are safe** (fail closed, not open)

## Documentation Standards

### Code Documentation
- [ ] **Package comments explain purpose** not just name
- [ ] **Exported types and functions documented**
- [ ] **Comments explain WHY** not WHAT
- [ ] **Edge cases documented** in comments
- [ ] **Assumptions stated explicitly**
- [ ] **TODO comments actionable** (no vague TODOs)
- [ ] **NO compatibility TODO comments** ("remove after migration")

### API Documentation
- [ ] **REST endpoints documented** with request/response examples
- [ ] **WebSocket protocol documented** with message formats
- [ ] **Error responses documented** with status codes
- [ ] **Rate limits documented** clearly

## Code Organization

### Package Structure
- [ ] **Single responsibility** per package
- [ ] **Interfaces small and focused** (1-3 methods ideal)
- [ ] **Interfaces defined at usage point** not with implementation
- [ ] **Standard library interfaces** used when applicable
- [ ] **Circular dependencies avoided**

### Design Patterns
- [ ] **Composition over inheritance** used
- [ ] **"Accept interfaces, return structs"** pattern followed
- [ ] **Synchronous by default** - let callers handle concurrency
- [ ] **Minimal abstractions** - obvious solutions preferred
- [ ] **DRY principle** - repeated code extracted
- [ ] **YAGNI principle** - no speculative features

## Final Checks

### Critical Standards
- [ ] **All financial math uses decimal** - NO EXCEPTIONS
- [ ] **No backwards compatibility** - NO EXCEPTIONS
- [ ] **All tests pass** - NO SKIPPED TESTS
- [ ] **Clean git history** - no "Generated with Claude" messages
- [ ] **go fmt applied** to all files
- [ ] **go vet passes** without warnings
- [ ] **Race detector clean** (`go test -race`)

### Performance Verification
- [ ] **Benchmarks show acceptable performance**
- [ ] **Memory usage profiled** for leaks
- [ ] **CPU profile shows** no obvious bottlenecks
- [ ] **Graceful degradation** under load

## Review Sign-off

**Reviewer**: _______________  
**Date**: _______________  
**Status**: [ ] APPROVED [ ] NEEDS CHANGES [ ] REJECTED

### Required for Approval
1. All CRITICAL items must pass
2. No backwards compatibility code present
3. All financial calculations use decimal
4. All tests pass without skips
5. Clean breaks enforced throughout

### Comments
```
[Specific issues requiring fixes]
```

---

## Quick Reference

### Commands to Run Before Review
```bash
# Format check
go fmt ./...

# Vet check
go vet ./...

# Test with race detector
go test -race ./...

# Test coverage
go test -cover ./...

# Benchmark performance
go test -bench=. ./...

# Check for decimal usage in financial code
grep -r "float64\|float32" --include="*.go" | grep -E "(price|amount|quantity|fee|balance|pnl)"
```

### Red Flags - Immediate Rejection
1. `float64` used for money/prices
2. `_v2.go` or similar variant files
3. `Deprecated:` comments
4. `TODO: remove after migration`
5. `if useOldVersion {`
6. `t.Skip()` in tests
7. Backwards compatibility adapters
8. Version-specific API endpoints (/v1, /v2)

### Green Flags - Good Patterns
1. `decimal.Decimal` for all financial values
2. Clean, direct error returns
3. Table-driven tests with subtests
4. Context cancellation handled
5. Resources cleaned up with defer
6. Breaking changes that force compilation failures
7. Concise, clear naming
8. Comprehensive error wrapping

## Recommendation: Yes, add "no magic numbers" rule

Added to `/back/.docs/code/review.md` after analyzing the codebase. Found magic numbers in:
- Time durations (`30 * time.Second`)
- Trading thresholds (`0.7`, `0.3` body ratios)
- Buffer sizes (`4096`)

**Decision**: Added pragmatic rule to review.md with clear exceptions (array indices, percentage math, test data). No separate constants-patterns.md file needed - keeps it simple per Big Meanie philosophy.

The rule now appears in the review checklist with practical guidance on when constants are required vs when inline numbers are acceptable.

     2â†’
     3â†’## Table of Contents
     4â†’1. [Introduction](#introduction)
     5â†’2. [Basic Syntax](#basic-syntax)
     6â†’3. [Variables and Constants](#variables-and-constants)
     7â†’4. [Data Types](#data-types)
     8â†’5. [Control Flow](#control-flow)
     9â†’6. [Functions](#functions)
    10â†’7. [Methods](#methods)
    11â†’8. [Structs](#structs)
    12â†’9. [Interfaces](#interfaces)
    13â†’10. [Pointers](#pointers)
    14â†’11. [Arrays and Slices](#arrays-and-slices)
    15â†’12. [Maps](#maps)
    16â†’13. [Error Handling](#error-handling)
    17â†’14. [Packages and Modules](#packages-and-modules)
    18â†’15. [Type Assertions and Type Switches](#type-assertions-and-type-switches)
    19â†’16. [Embedding and Composition](#embedding-and-composition)
    20â†’17. [Generics](#generics)
    21â†’
    22â†’## Introduction
    23â†’
    24â†’Go is a statically typed, compiled language designed for simplicity, efficiency, and reliable software. Created at Google in 2007 by Robert Griesemer, Rob Pike, and Ken Thompson, Go combines the performance of compiled languages with the ease of programming of dynamic languages.
    25â†’
    26â†’### Core Philosophy
    27â†’- **Simplicity**: Less is exponentially more
    28â†’- **Readability**: Code is read more often than written
    29â†’- **Efficiency**: Fast compilation, fast execution
    30â†’- **Concurrency**: Built-in primitives for concurrent programming
    31â†’- **Pragmatism**: Solve real problems with practical solutions
    32â†’
    33â†’## Basic Syntax
    34â†’
    35â†’### Program Structure
    36â†’
    37â†’Every Go program starts with a package declaration and imports:
    38â†’
    39â†’```go
    40â†’package main
    41â†’
    42â†’import (
    43â†’    "fmt"
    44â†’    "strings"
    45â†’    "time"
    46â†’)
    47â†’
    48â†’func main() {
    49â†’    fmt.Println("Hello, Go!")
    50â†’}
    51â†’```
    52â†’
    53â†’### Comments
    54â†’
    55â†’```go
    56â†’// Single-line comment
    57â†’
    58â†’/*
    59â†’   Multi-line comment
    60â†’   Can span multiple lines
    61â†’*/
    62â†’
    63â†’// Package documentation comment (must precede package declaration)
    64â†’// Package math provides basic mathematical functions.
    65â†’package math
    66â†’
    67â†’// Function documentation (must precede function declaration)
    68â†’// Add returns the sum of two integers.
    69â†’func Add(a, b int) int {
    70â†’    return a + b
    71â†’}
    72â†’```
    73â†’
    74â†’### Naming Conventions
    75â†’
    76â†’```go
    77â†’// Exported (public) - starts with uppercase
    78â†’type Strategy struct{}
    79â†’func CalculateProfit() {}
    80â†’const MaxRetries = 3
    81â†’var DefaultTimeout = 5 * time.Second
    82â†’
    83â†’// Unexported (private) - starts with lowercase
    84â†’type position struct{}
    85â†’func calculateLoss() {}
    86â†’const maxAttempts = 5
    87â†’var defaultBuffer = 1024
    88â†’
    89â†’// Package names - lowercase, single word
    90â†’package trading  // Good
    91â†’package tradingEngine  // Bad - use trading or engine
    92â†’
    93â†’// Interface names - typically end with -er
    94â†’type Reader interface{}
    95â†’type Writer interface{}
    96â†’type Closer interface{}
    97â†’type ReadWriteCloser interface{}  // Composition
    98â†’
    99â†’// Acronyms - keep consistent case
   100â†’var httpClient HTTP  // Bad
   101â†’var HTTPClient HTTP  // Good
   102â†’var xmlParser XML    // Bad
   103â†’var XMLParser XML    // Good
   104â†’```
   105â†’
   106â†’## Variables and Constants
   107â†’
   108â†’### Variable Declaration
   109â†’
   110â†’```go
   111â†’// var declaration with type
   112â†’var name string
   113â†’var age int
   114â†’var balance float64
   115â†’
   116â†’// var declaration with initialization
   117â†’var name string = "John"
   118â†’var age int = 30
   119â†’var balance = 1000.50  // Type inferred
   120â†’
   121â†’// Short variable declaration (only inside functions)
   122â†’name := "John"
   123â†’age := 30
   124â†’balance := 1000.50
   125â†’
   126â†’// Multiple variable declaration
   127â†’var (
   128â†’    firstName string = "John"
   129â†’    lastName  string = "Doe"
   130â†’    age       int    = 30
   131â†’)
   132â†’
   133â†’// Multiple assignment
   134â†’x, y := 10, 20
   135â†’a, b = b, a  // Swap values
   136â†’
   137â†’// Blank identifier for unused values
   138â†’_, err := someFunction()  // Ignore first return value
   139â†’```
   140â†’
   141â†’### Constants
   142â†’
   143â†’```go
   144â†’// Single constant
   145â†’const Pi = 3.14159

   148â†’
   149â†’// Typed constants
   150â†’const MaxInt int = 1000

   152â†’
   153â†’// Multiple constants
   154â†’const (
   155â†’    StatusOK       = 200
   156â†’    StatusNotFound = 404
   157â†’    StatusError    = 500
   158â†’)
   159â†’
   160â†’// iota - constant generator
   161â†’const (
   162â†’    Sunday = iota  // 0
   163â†’    Monday         // 1
   164â†’    Tuesday        // 2
   165â†’    Wednesday      // 3
   166â†’    Thursday       // 4
   167â†’    Friday         // 5
   168â†’    Saturday       // 6
   169â†’)
   170â†’
   171â†’// iota with expressions
   172â†’const (
   173â†’    _  = iota             // 0 (ignored)
   174â†’    KB = 1 << (10 * iota) // 1024
   175â†’    MB                    // 1048576
   176â†’    GB                    // 1073741824
   177â†’    TB                    // 1099511627776
   178â†’)
   179â†’
   180â†’// Bit flags with iota
   181â†’const (
   182â†’    ReadPermission = 1 << iota  // 1
   183â†’    WritePermission              // 2
   184â†’    ExecutePermission            // 4
   185â†’)

   188â†’## Data Types
   189â†’
   190â†’### Basic Types
   191â†’
   192â†’```go

   201â†’var i64 int64 = 9223372036854775807  // -9223372036854775808 to 9223372036854775807
   202â†’var i int = 42                       // Platform dependent (32 or 64 bit)
   203â†’
   204â†’// Unsigned integers

   208â†’var ui64 uint64 = 18446744073709551615  // 0 to 18446744073709551615
   209â†’var ui uint = 42                     // Platform dependent

   213â†’var f64 float64 = 3.141592653589793  // IEEE-754 64-bit
   214â†’

   233â†’### Type Conversions
   234â†’
   235â†’```go
   236â†’// Explicit type conversion required
   237â†’var i int = 42
   238â†’var f float64 = float64(i)
   239â†’var u uint = uint(i)
   240â†’
   241â†’// String conversions
   242â†’import "strconv"
   243â†’
   244â†’// Int to string

   247â†’
   248â†’// String to int
   249â†’i, err := strconv.Atoi("42")
   250â†’i64, err := strconv.ParseInt("42", 10, 64)
   251â†’

   253â†’s := strconv.FormatFloat(3.14, 'f', 2, 64)  // 2 decimal places
   254â†’

   256â†’f, err := strconv.ParseFloat("3.14", 64)
   257â†’
   258â†’// Type assertions (for interfaces)
   259â†’var x interface{} = "hello"
   260â†’s := x.(string)  // Panics if x is not string
   261â†’s, ok := x.(string)  // Safe assertion with ok check

   280â†’## Control Flow
   281â†’
   282â†’### If Statements
   283â†’
   284â†’```go
   285â†’// Basic if
   286â†’if x > 0 {
   287â†’    fmt.Println("Positive")
   288â†’}
   289â†’
   290â†’// If-else
   291â†’if x > 0 {
   292â†’    fmt.Println("Positive")
   293â†’} else {
   294â†’    fmt.Println("Non-positive")
   295â†’}
   296â†’
   297â†’// If-else if-else
   298â†’if x > 0 {
   299â†’    fmt.Println("Positive")
   300â†’} else if x < 0 {
   301â†’    fmt.Println("Negative")
   302â†’} else {
   303â†’    fmt.Println("Zero")
   304â†’}
   305â†’
   306â†’// If with initialization
   307â†’if err := doSomething(); err != nil {
   308â†’    return err  // err is scoped to if block
   309â†’}
   310â†’
   311â†’// Common patterns
   312â†’// Check error immediately
   313â†’if err != nil {
   314â†’    return fmt.Errorf("failed to process: %w", err)
   315â†’}
   316â†’
   317â†’// Check boolean
   318â†’if !isValid {
   319â†’    return errors.New("invalid input")
   320â†’}
   321â†’
   322â†’// Check nil
   323â†’if data == nil {
   324â†’    return errors.New("data is nil")
   325â†’}
   326â†’```
   327â†’
   328â†’### Switch Statements
   329â†’
   330â†’```go
   331â†’// Basic switch
   332â†’switch day {
   333â†’case "Monday":
   334â†’    fmt.Println("Start of work week")
   335â†’case "Friday":
   336â†’    fmt.Println("TGIF!")
   337â†’case "Saturday", "Sunday":
   338â†’    fmt.Println("Weekend!")
   339â†’default:
   340â†’    fmt.Println("Midweek")
   341â†’}
   342â†’
   343â†’// Switch with no expression (like if-else chain)
   344â†’switch {
   345â†’case x < 0:
   346â†’    fmt.Println("Negative")
   347â†’case x == 0:
   348â†’    fmt.Println("Zero")
   349â†’case x > 0:
   350â†’    fmt.Println("Positive")
   351â†’}
   352â†’
   353â†’// Switch with initialization
   354â†’switch os := runtime.GOOS; os {
   355â†’case "darwin":
   356â†’    fmt.Println("macOS")
   357â†’case "linux":
   358â†’    fmt.Println("Linux")
   359â†’default:
   360â†’    fmt.Printf("Unknown OS: %s\n", os)
   361â†’}
   362â†’
   363â†’// Type switch
   364â†’func describe(i interface{}) {
   365â†’    switch v := i.(type) {
   366â†’    case int:
   367â†’        fmt.Printf("Integer: %d\n", v)
   368â†’    case string:
   369â†’        fmt.Printf("String: %s\n", v)
   370â†’    case bool:
   371â†’        fmt.Printf("Boolean: %t\n", v)
   372â†’    case nil:
   373â†’        fmt.Println("nil value")
   374â†’    default:
   375â†’        fmt.Printf("Unknown type: %T\n", v)
   376â†’    }
   377â†’}
   378â†’
   379â†’// Fallthrough (rarely used)
   380â†’switch num {
   381â†’case 1:
   382â†’    fmt.Println("One")
   383â†’    fallthrough  // Continue to next case
   384â†’case 2:
   385â†’    fmt.Println("One or Two")
   386â†’}
   387â†’```
